@@2907736 <p> I neglected to mention in the orginal post that I still own twelve Par38 fixtures ... I think . It has been a while since I tracked them all down and counted , but that sounds right . I know I have six in one box and I think I saw at least four more on the shelf last night ... who knows ? Mostly gelled with R33 ( No Color Pink ) and R01 ( Lt Bastard Amber ) and R60 ( No Color Blue ) and R120 ( Red Diffusion ) and R121 ( Blue Diffusion ) . I use the same gel colors on my Par64 ... and usually have at least one or more spare sheets of each color as well as several gels in both Par38 and Par64 sizes . <p> And now to the response to Mike : <p> ======================== <p> You can take a Par38 such as you described and place it on a round , cast mic stand base using a bolt , nut and large washers and you have an UP LIGHTING FIXTURE . I often take one or two @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ in the corners ... I also will use those " party colored " CFL light bulbs ... typically the blue and the red ... in a Par38 fixture for those " up lighting " assignments . Low heat , thus less likely to be a risk if curtains come into contact with the fixture ... unlike a 90 Watt Halogen . <p> According to my lighting guru ... 20 Amp wall circuit ( notice I said 20 Amp , not the typical 15 Amp ... so adjust accordingly ) .... <p> So , to specifically answer your question , " How many Par64 will a 20 Amp circuit support safely ? " It depends on the lamps you use ... you should be able to safely handle four 500 Watt Par64 ( or other instrument using 500 Watt bulbs/lamps ) on a typical 20 Amp circuit . <p> ( I typed the above prior to reading Boomer and D.Parker 's responses ... glad to see they agree with my guru 's advice and my own experience . ) <p> Since I own five of the DP-415 , I often find @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ support a total of four 500 Watt fixtures . Wastefull ? Yep , but ya got ta do what ya got ta do , ya know ? When I do that , I put gaff tape over channels 1 and 2 on one dimmer and over 3 and 4 on a second dimmer and then mount both on the T-bar . Then repeat for the other tripod stand . <p> This current event , we acquired eight 1000 Watt Par64 lamps so we could reduce the number of fixtures over the dance floor . In the past , we had a much larger dance floor and since the " dancing with the local stars " was the focus of the fundraiser , we needed better coverage . Since the dance floor is secondary , we are increasig the individual output , but reducing the number of fixtures on the dance floor ... thus we will not have as good coverage , but should still have plenty of " color " for the dance floor wash . <p> The dance floor wash is strictly Red and Blue diffusion . <p> To @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ one 20 Amp dimmer for every two 1000 Watt fixtures ... and that means I have to have two 20 Amp circuits to each rack of four 1000 Watt Par64 . <p> For the front of the stage ( for the " talent show " ) we are using four 750 Watt leko style elipsoidal spots AND six 500 Watt Par64 . We will place two leko and three Par64 on each of the two bars along with two DP-415 dimmers per bar . One 15 Amp dimmer for the leko instruments and the other for the Par64 . <p> That leaves me one DP-415 dimmer on each of the two sides of the stage and we will place three 500 Watt Par 64 on each side of the stage . <p> We will be using a 3 or 4 color palette . " Warm " ; " Cool " ; and " Neutral " . I know we are using R33 as our Neutral .. for visibility ... I think we are using some R27 medium red and R83 medium blue for the warm and cool . ( not @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ director " . ) <p> That still leaves one DP-415 dimmer and four 500 Watt Par64 that I can place on the band along with my ADJ P64LED fixtures . I will put the dimmer on one tripod for two of the Par64 and run a couple of extension cords to the opposite tripod to support the other two Par64 one the same dimmer . I will just use a two color wash on the band and NEVER run those channels above 50-60% hoping against hope that I do n't trip a breaker or blow a fuse in the dimmer . <p> I should note that light fixtures are no " linear " in power consumption . So , 75% of the fader does NOT equal 75% of the Wattage of the device . <p> **36;2097;TOOLONG <p> Mike , for what its worth ... <p> When I bought my first 500 Watt Par64 , I only had six 500 W Par64 ... and I was able to put three per side using the DP-415 with NO problems . @@2907739 <p> **41;2135;TOOLONG had an uncanny ability to locate Wild Bunch arms , a hyper-active imagination , or both . He suggested that he might have located another Colt , in the ruins of the Castle Gate , Utah , mine office held up by Cassidy in 1897 . It could have been dropped by the bandit or by one of the payroll defenders , Larson said , covering his bets . He also claimed that he owned C.L. " Gunplay Maxwells Colt .44-40 and one or more of Harvey Logans Colt .45s . Larson was a celebrity-outlaw gun magnet . In a 1969 article for Guns , Larson said that he had found a Colt .45 that Logan had traded to a " close kin " of Cassidys family for a " four-year old sorrel mare . " In case there was any doubt , the Colt was conveniently inscribed " H.L. " As proof of the trade , Larson produced a tattered note , signed W.R. Parker , that looked more like a comic-book illustration . He described the Wild Bunch as a gang that " reached army proportions @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Larson spelled " Dialo , " had chased Logan , which he never did ; and told the cornball tale of Logan having given a woman " a brooch and helped her across the street " during the Winnemucca holdup . Seven years later , Larson disclosed that he had located Logans " most favored " gun , a factory-engraved Colt .45 Single Action Army that he had taken off Charles Judd , " a well known trick shot artist " and Colt salesman , during the 1899 Wilcox holdup . According to Larson , deputy sheriff Fred Carlson had retrieved the gun from Logans body after his suicide at Parachute in 1904 . An inconvenient fact is that no passengers were robbed during the Wilcox heist , and a second is that there 's no record of a lawman named Fred Carlson being involved in the 1904 chase . Larson further egged the omelet by asserting that Logan re-stole the Judd Colt while escaping from the Knoxville jail in 1903 , kidnaping the sheriff in the process . He did escape , but with his guards weapons and without abducting @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ two revolvers were still in the custody of a federal court in Knoxville . The Judd Colt story is even more convoluted . There 's yet another Colt linked to Logan , which he reportedly stole " from a firearms salesman on a train , " and later gave to a friend , and which still later was sold to collector John E. Bianchi , who subsequently sold his collection to the Autry Museum . Larsons name has n't  surfaced directly in reference to this particular Colt , because its precise provenance is sketchy , but William Darby , the friend Logan gave it to as the story goes figures in the history of the Cassidy amnesty Colt. **32;2178;TOOLONG <p> I could n't find an answer online , and I was wondering--has the Charles Judd .45 , supposedly found on the Parachute man , ever been debunked ? @@2907740 <p> In a controversial decision that shocked children 's advocates , an Ohio judge has given the greenlight for the spanking of teenage schoolgirls on their bare-bottoms . <p> Mason Municipal Court Judge George Parker ruled that it was " appropriate " for 49 year-old Gary Freudenthal of Blue Ash , Ohio to pull down the panties of a 14-year old teenage girl and repeatedly spank her on her bare bottom for staying out late the night before . <p> " I spanked her hard enough so she could feel it ... so it would sting , so she would n't be able to sit down , so she would remember it , " Mr. Freudenthal testified . " She was so out of control . " <p> Freudenthal is a friend of the girl 's grandmother ( her legal guardian ) and the single father of the spanked girl 's female friend . <p> The girl 's grandmother said she never gave Freudenthal permission to strike her granddaughter . That did not matter to Judge Parker . <p> After the girl attended a football game with his daughter and @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ to the girl 's grandmother 's home in Mason about 9:30 AM the next morning . He entered the house and walked into the girl 's bedroom where she was sleeping in bed . After pulling down the bedcovers , he grabbed the underwear-clad girl , placed her over his knee and spanked her over her panties . <p> Freudenthal said that when the girl laughed , he decided a more humiliating and shameful punishment was necessary . So he pulled down her panties , completely exposing the teenage girl 's bare bottom , and spanked her even harder . <p> A police officer who later interviewed and observed the girl 's bare bottom testified that the spanking caused bruising on the girl 's upper legs and buttocks . <p> City Prosecutor Robert Peeler had argued to the Court that the issue was clear-cut : " Did Freudenthal commit an act where he caused or attempted to cause physical harm ? " to the teen , which are the elements of a misdemeanor assault charge . <p> " This case was about whether a 49-year-old man has the right to @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ pants of the 14 year-old girl and strike her , " Mr. Peeler said . <p> But Judge Parker disagreed and ruled there was nothing wrong about the bare-bottom spanking . <p> Children 's advocates , however , were appalled . <p> " It sounds like assault . There is no authority I 'm aware of that gives someone who is not the parent the right to spank or hit the child , " said Yvette McGee Brown , president of the Center for Child and Family Advocacy in Columbus . <p> Nadine A. Block , executive director of the Center for Effective Discipline , a Columbus-based national organization that opposes corporal punishment agreed . <p> " You ca n't hit a neighbor 's dog , so what was he doing hitting a teen-age girl ? " she noted . <p> But pro-spanking advocates , like Freudenthal , were ecstatic that the ruling could give a greenlight to more widespread bare-bottom spankings of girls , perhaps even in school in front of their classmates , as a method of discipline for their poor behavior . <p> " Parents should be @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ control their children , " said Freudenthal , indicating perhaps that any child guardian , even a school teacher , should be able to pull down a girl 's panties and spank her for disciplinary reasons . <p> Lest you think Judge Parker is a lone nutcase in Little Wet Dreamland , there are plenty of men in government who feel that thousands of other teenage girls should be disciplined in this same humiliating manner . <p> The Texas legislature , without one single dissenting vote , passed in 2005 a bill which gives virtually anyone the same rights as Freudenthal . That is , to discipline a girl as he or she sees reasonable , which very well could include the shame and embarrassment of suffering a bare bottom spanking in the classroom in front of classmates . <p> HB 383 states : AN ACT relating to the right of certain persons to discipline a child . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF TEXAS : SECTION 1 . Section 151.001 , Family Code , is amended byadding Subsection ( e ) to read as follows @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ corporal punishmentfor the reasonable discipline of a child : ( 1 ) a parent or grandparent of the child ; ( 2 ) a stepparent of the child who has the duty ofcontrol and reasonable discipline of the child ; and ( 3 ) an individual who is a guardian of the child andwho has the duty of control and reasonable discipline of the child . SECTION 2 . This Act takes effect immediately if it receivesa vote of two-thirds of all the members elected to each house , asprovided by Section 39 , Article III , Texas Constitution . If thisAct does not receive the vote necessary for immediate effect , thisAct takes effect September 1 , 2005 . The bill was later signed into law by Governor Rick Perry . <p> " I do n't ever see a need to hit another human being . We only hit children because they are smaller than us , " she said . <p> But regrettably , not even she had the courage to object when HB 383 came to a vote . <p> From personal experience I can say it @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of my classmates when I was in first and second grade . Having to face my teachers after the infrequent spankings I did receive , not to mention my classmates who witnessed and teased me about those spankings , was a constant reminder of my shame . But to suffer those punishments as a teenager in high school in front of my classmates and with my panties completely lowered would have been humiliating beyond belief . <p> Yet I am certain that if I had more teachers who believed in delivering shameful corporal punishments like Judge Parker and Gary Freudenthal subscribe to , my panties would have frequently hit the floor all the way into and through my high school years . I would have been left with no choice but to meekly blush and accept the embarrassment , humiliation and shame that comes from being spanked while totally exposed and naked from the waist down in front of my classmates . <p> Let there be no doubt : to be stripped of your panties , of your modesty , and of your dignity and then to be spanked on @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of others , leaves us girls feeling utterly ashamed and with a long-lasting impression of our punishment . <p> Freudenthal is correct about one thing . @@2907743 <p> I can offer a bit of chronology on Joseph W. Mason , coming from various sources . <p> Earliest I have on Mason is the 1870 Census which shows he was born in England in 1844 . About this time Joe was living in " Wild &amp; Woolly " Hays City , Kansas , working in Jim Beardsleys saloon . All kinds of future Dodge City men were at Hays at this time - to name a few - Ed Hougue , A.J. Peacock , Charlie Bassett , " Prairrie Dog " Dave Morrow , Larry Deger , Jack Bridges , Joe Mason , future mayors and other movers and shakers . <p> By 1875 Joe is an Army Scout working out of Fort Dodge , Kansas . He is enumerated on the Dodge City Census for that year , while his younger brother James Mason is listed as " Clerk . " <p> Mason was never appointed an officer by Wyatt Earp in 1876 , as was claimed by Earp . <p> In 1877 his tenure as policeman was May 9 through October 2 . During that cattle @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ his work as policeman partnered with Ed Masterson . He was noted for the pair of ivory-handled Colts ( in holsters ) that he wore while patrolling the streets . It was said Joe was especially admired by the " ladies " and known as the " Apollo of Dodge . " Besides the pearl handles and keeping a " glittering police star " Joe sported " immaculate topboots . " <p> Possibly some of the " doves " were looking to get his attention in odd ways . In June 1877 a fighting breed of doves was reported on in " A Battle of the Beauties " article which described how two girls " fell to pulling hair and kicking shins . Just as the combat deepened and the prospect for two bald-headed maidens was was bright , the irrepressible Joe Mason sallied in and restore the peace and dignity of the city . " <p> Teaming up with Under Sheriff Bat Masterson in July they took off after some horse thieves . According the D.C. Times , Mason and Bat got the drop of them : " Masterson @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ made him a prisoner Mason pointed two ivory-handled guns at another , and completely covered him . " <p> In one week in September Joe was mentioned for having mad six arrests . <p> Dismissed as officer at the end of the season Joe was mentioned on October 6 as being houseman/bartender at the famous Long Branch Saloon . <p> Around October 1 , 1877 Wyatt Earp , who I believe worked under payroll of the sheriffs department that summer , left town and went to Texas . According to Kate ( Elder ) Holliday , Joe Masons girl friend in Dodge at this time was a " Mattie , " when Wyatt " was out of town . " For some unknown reason Mattie and Joe had a falling out by end of year . Records show Mason working as deputy sheriff one week - December 1 through December 8 . According to archive sources Joe had Mattie put in jail until she paid a fine of $39.50 . ( ? ? ) <p> Later in December Mason showed up at Mobeetie , Texas , joining a whole bunch @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ vice . They quickly put him to work as bartender/houseman - just like previously at Hays and Dodge Cities . Kate ( Elder ) Holliday was also there in Mobeetie working under J.S. Elder and Tom Sherman ; the latters dance hall where she had worked at Dodge . <p> On January 12 , 1878 , bartending in Mobeetie , Mason shot and killed one Edward Ryan , another former Dodge City gunman . Incidentally , Joe later received a congratulatory letter from former neighbors of Ed Ryan in a Northern State . <p> In the spring 1878 Joe was back in Dodge City . In April he was reappointed to the police force , and Wyatt Earp was later placed on the force again that year . This would have been for the encroaching Texas Longhorn cattle season once again . About this time Officer Joe Masson had to break up an hellacious scene on Front Street , where paying customers were watching two black men engaged in a duel with bull whips . Mason put a stop to the bloody carnage . <p> In 1880 Joe served as @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Camp Supply a little bear cub and gave it to the Mayor James Kelley . The cub was named " Paddy-the-Bear " and became a prominent character around Front Street . When it became full grown there were some big problems in Dodge for a while , due to prankster slipping Paddy shots of whiskey . <p> Kenny , this is simply a great post ! Far more information than I expected . Thank you very much ! The little bit of info I have complements yours . On May 9 , 1877 when Joe Mason was appointed Dodge City ... more <p> Dear Kenny , This is wonderful ! ! It clarifies so many discrepencies and am thrilled with all of the new info ... love the bear story ! You have made my day ! Thank YOU so much ! @@2907746 <p> ODF militiamen Frank Delollis , right , signals for a patrol party to turn around while searching the Old Roseville Prison property in Roseville , Ohio for enemy combatants during the Ohio Defense Force 's annual FTX on Aug. 21 , 2010 . <p> Ty Cacek for TIME <p> Camouflaged and silent , the assault team inched toward a walled stone compound for more than five hours , belly-crawling the last 200 yards . The target was an old state prison in eastern Ohio , and every handpicked member of Red Team 2 knew what was at stake : The year is 2014 , and a new breed of neo-Islamic terrorism is rampant in Michigan , Illinois , Indiana and Ohio ... The current White House Administration is pro-Muslim and has ordered a stand-down against Islamic groups . The mission : Destroy the terrorist command post or die trying . The fighters must go in " sterile " without name tags or other identifying insignia as a deniable covert force . " Anyone who is caught or captured can not expect extraction , " the briefing officer said . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ , sharp bursts from their M-16s cut down the perimeter guards . Once past the rear gate , the raiders fanned out and emptied clip after clip in a barrage of diversionary fire . As defenders rushed to repel the small team , the main assault force struck from the opposite flank . Red Team 1 burst through a chain-link fence , enveloping the defense in lethal cross fire . The shooting was over in minutes . Thick grenade smoke bloomed over the command post . The defenders were routed , headquarters ablaze . ( Watch TIME 's video " Homeland Security Tradeshow . " ) <p> This August weekend of grueling mock combat , which left some of the men prostrate and bloody-booted , capped a yearlong training regimen of the Ohio Defense Force , a private militia that claims 300 active members statewide . The fighters shot blanks , the better to learn to maneuver in squads , but they buy live ammunition in bulk . Their training no game , they stress expends thousands of rounds a year from a bring-your-own armory of deer rifles , assault @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ belt-fed M-60 machine gun . The militia trains for ambushes , sniper missions , close-quarters battle and other infantry staples . <p> What distinguishes groups like this one from a shooting club or re-enactment society is the prospect of actual bloodshed , which many Ohio Defense Force members see as real . Their unit seal depicts a man with a musket and tricorn hat , over the motto " Today 's Minutemen . " The symbol invites a question , Who are today 's redcoats ? On that point , the group takes no official position , but many of those interviewed over two days of recent training in and around the abandoned Roseville State Prison near Zanesville voiced grim suspicions about President Obama and the federal government in general . ( See Obama 's troubled first year . ) <p> " I do n't know who the redcoats are , " says Brian Vandersall , 37 , who designed the exercise and tried to tamp down talk of politics among the men . " It could be U.N . troops . It could be federal troops . It could @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ could be Mexican troops who are crossing the border . " <p> Or it could be , as it was for this year 's exercise , an Islamic army marauding unchecked because a hypothetical pro-Muslim President has ordered U.S. forces to leave them alone . But as the drill played out , the designated opponents bore little resemblance to terrorists . The scenario described them as a platoon-size unit , in uniform , with " military-grade hardware , communications , encryption capability and vehicle support . " The militia was training for combat against the spitting image of a tactical force from the Bureau of Alcohol , Tobacco , Firearms and Explosives ( ATF ) , FBI or National Guard . " Whoever they are , " Vandersall says , " we have to be ready . " <p> As militias go , the Ohio Defense Force is on the moderate side . Scores of armed antigovernment groups , some of them far more radical , have formed or been revived during the Obama years , according to law-enforcement agencies and outside watchdogs . A six-month TIME investigation reveals that @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ shooting war are on the rise , as are criminal investigations by the FBI and state authorities . Readier for bloodshed than at any time since at least the confrontations in the 1990s in Ruby Ridge , Idaho , and Waco , Texas , the radical right has raised the threat level against the President and other government targets . With violence already up on a modest scale , FBI , Department of Homeland Security ( DHS ) and state agencies point to two main dangers of a mass-casualty attack : that a group of armed radicals will strike out in perceived self-defense , or that a lone wolf , trained and indoctrinated for war , will grow tired of waiting . Even the most outspoken militia commanders worry about the latter scenario . Kevin Terrell , a self-described colonel who founded a group of " freedom fighters " in Kentucky and predicts war with " the jackbooted thugs " of Washington within a year , says he has to fend off hotheads who call him a " keyboard commando . " Some are ejected from his group , he @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ longer . " You have to have the right fuel-air mixture , the piston has to be in the right position , the spark has to be perfectly timed , " he says . " The day will come sooner than later . " <p> Twisted PatriotsWithin a complex web of ideologies , most of today 's armed radicals are linked by self-described Patriot beliefs , which emphasize resistance to tyranny by force of arms and reject the idea that elections can fix what ails the country . Among the most common convictions is that the Second Amendment the right to keep and bear arms is the Constitution 's cornerstone , because only a well-armed populace can enforce its rights . Any form of gun regulation , therefore , is a sure sign of intent to crush other freedoms . The federal government is often said in militia circles to have made wholesale seizures of power , at times by subterfuge . A leading grievance holds that the 16th Amendment , which authorizes the federal income tax , was ratified through fraud . ( Read " America 's New Patriotism @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ the armed antigovernment movement describes itself as heir to the founders . As they see it , the union that the founders created is now a foreign tyrant . " It 's like waking up behind enemy lines , " says Terrell . He says he smelled a setup when the FBI arrested nine members of Michigan 's Hutaree militia in March and charged them with plotting to kill police . ( Their trial is set to begin in February . ) Terrell and other leaders put their forces on alert , anticipating a roundup . " There was a lot of citizens out there in the bushes , locked and loaded , " he says . " It 's only due to miracles I do not understand that civil war did not break out right there . " <p> Some groups , though not many overtly , embrace the white-supremacist legacy of the Posse Comitatus , which invented the modern militia movement in the 1970s . Some are fueled by a violent stream of millennial Christianity . Some believe Washington is a secondary foe , the agent of a @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ number of these extremist groups , according to the FBI , ATF and state investigators , are subjects of active criminal investigations . They include militias and other promoters of armed confrontation with government , among them " common-law jurors , " who try to make their own arrests and convene their own trials , and " sovereign citizens , " who respond with lethal force to routine encounters with the law . In April , for example , Navy veteran Walter Fitzpatrick , acting on behalf of a group called American Grand Jury , barged into a Tennessee courthouse and tried to arrest the real grand-jury foreman on the grounds that he refused to indict Obama for treason . In May , Georgia militia member Darren Huff was arrested by Tennessee state troopers after telling them that he and other armed men intended to " take over the Monroe County courthouse , " free Fitzpatrick and " conduct arrests " of other officials , according to Huff 's indictment and his own account in an interview posted online . Investigators are keeping a wary eye on a related trend @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ which law officers and military service members vow to refuse or resist orders they deem unconstitutional . About a dozen county sheriffs and several candidates for sheriff in the midterm elections have threatened to arrest federal agents in their jurisdictions . <p> Group distinctions are seldom clear because of overlapping memberships and alliances . The Ohio exercise , for example , included a delegation from the 17th Special Operations Group led by Colonel Dick Wolf , a former Army drill sergeant who previously took a unit to join Arizona militia leader Chris Simcox in armed patrols along the Mexican border . Wolf travels around the country to train other groups in such skills as knife fighting and convoy operations . He does not ask about their philosophies . " That 's their business , " he says . <p> The Obama FactorNone of these movements are entirely new , but most were in sharp decline by the late 1990s . Their resurgence now is widely seen among government and academic experts as a reaction to the tectonic shifts in American politics that allowed a black man with a foreign-sounding name @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ ( See pictures of Muslim in America . ) <p> Obama 's ascendancy unhinged the radical right , offering a unified target to competing camps of racial , nativist and religious animus . Even Patriots who had no truck with white supremacy found that they could amplify their antigovernment message by " constructing Obama as an alien , not of this country , insufficiently American , " according to Michael Waltman , an authority on hate speech at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill . Perennial features of extreme-right scare lore including imagined schemes to declare martial law , abolish private ownership of guns and force dissidents into FEMA concentration camps became more potent with Obama as the Commander in Chief . <p> Threats against Obama 's life brought him Secret Service protection in May 2007 , by far the earliest on record for a presidential candidate . At least four alleged assassination plots between June and December by militiamen in Pennsylvania , white supremacists in Denver , skinheads in Tennessee and an active-duty Marine lance corporal at North Carolina 's Camp Lejeune led to arrests and criminal @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ We call it somewhat of a perfect storm , " says a high-ranking FBI official who declined to speak on the record because of the political sensitivities of the subject . With an economy in free fall and rising anger about illegal immigration , Obama became " a rallying point " for dormant extremists after the 2008 election who " were n't willing to act before but now are susceptible to being recruited and radicalized . " <p> Theirs is not Tea Party anger , which aims at electoral change , even if it often speaks of war . In the world of armed extremists , war is not always a metaphor . Some of them speak with contempt about big talkers who " meet , eat and retreat . " History suggests that even the most ferocious , by and large , will never get around to walking the walk . Mark Potok of the Southern Poverty Law Center observes that " there are huge numbers of people who say , ' We 're going to have to go to war to defend the Constitution or defend the white @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ , boys . ' " <p> And yet there are exceptions , and law-enforcement officials say domestic terrorists are equally the products of their movements . Those most inclined toward violence sometimes call themselves three percenters , a small vanguard that dares to match deeds to words . Brian Banning , who led local and interagency intelligence units that tracked radical-right-wing violence in Sacramento County , California , says , " The person who 's interested in violent revolution may be attracted to a racist group or to a militia or to the Tea Party because he 's antigovernment and so are they , but he 's looking on the fringe of the crowd for the people who want to take action . " ( See the top 10 inept terrorist plots . ) <p> The SupremacistOne such man was James Von Brunn . On June 10 , 2009 , he pulled up to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington , raised a .22-caliber rifle and shot security guard Stephen Tyrone Johns in the chest . Part of Von Brunn 's story is now well known , but police @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ epilogue . <p> MusterThe militia trains for ambushes , sniper missions , close-quarter battle and other types of military engagements . @@2907749 <p> There is not the slightest mention or use of the pagan Babylonian-Jewish luni-solar calender in the Gospels by Jesus or his followers , nor the Gospel writers themselves . This is a fact , evident from the staunch refusal to use the pagan Babylonian month names to date not even a single incident in the life of Jesus of Nazareth . Compare this with rabbinic writings which repeatedly use the pagan Babylonian month names over and over , including Josephus . <p> That the Gospel writings reflect the views of the Galilean sect is clear , so the Galilean Jews observed a sunrise-to-sunrise day reckoning of a solar 364-day calendar . Yet it is also clear that Gospels allude to how Judeans/Pharisees reckoned days from sunset . That is certainly not an endorsement else Matthew 28:1 and Luke 24:1 would not contradict Mark 16:9 and John 20:1 . Common sense and rationale thinking is not part of your vocabulary it seems . I have heard of Ockham 's Razor . Have you ? Matthew 28:1 states that it was still the Sabbath day and still dark , very early @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ tomb . Ockham 's Razor says to leave Matthew 28:1 alone and do n't force it out of context so that it is made to say the same thing as John 20:1 and Mark 16:9 . This is called manipulating the evidence to fit your theory . You do n't have to be published or a university faculty member to understand this , or maybe you do . <p> It is interesting that all Galileans , whenever they came to Jerusalem must have had a rocky and unstable situation because of the Pharisaic rules which dominated the city . Luke 13:1-2 tells us how some Pharisees were arguing with Jesus and told him that to be a " Galilean " was the same as being a sinner , and that this was proven from the fact that Pilate slaughtered some Galileans and mingled their blood with their own sacrifices . Pilate had no jurisdiction over Herod 's Galilee so this incident must have happened in Jerusalem when certain Galileans came there to sacrifice . It is also inconceivable that Pilate mixed human blood with the sacrifices inside the Temple . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ most likely in the dwelling places of the Galileans in Jerusalem where they made sacrifices separately and apart from the ones in the Temple that was dominated by Pharisees . It seems Pilate was moved by Pharisees to come down hard on Galileans visiting Jerusalem for not recognizing the legitimacy of the Pharisaic Temple liturgy . Galileans did not bring their sacrifices to the Temple . They came to Jerusalem annually and made sacrifices in their own homes . This was a rejection not of the Temple or the Torah but of the Jewish sect in control of the Temple and in control of how the Torah should be interpreted in Judea . <p> Jesus ' response to this attempt by Pharisees to degrade Galileans , and thus degrade Jesus the Galilean , did n't work : " You think these Galileans were sinners above all Galileans because they suffered such things ( from Pilate ) ? I tell you no . But except you repent you too will likewise perish . " <p> So my advice is that you should stop degrading Galileans as nincompoops ( who uses this @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ keeping the pagan Babylonian luni-solar calendar of the Pharisees . <p> " Galilean farmers seem to have adhered stubbornly to an ancient Israelite system of time-reckoning , which had been discarded by so-called Normative Judaism apparently already at some moment in the final quarter of the fourth century B.C. For the Synoptic Gospels and Acts , which , it may be said , in contrast to John , reflect the Galilean point of view and practice , still reckon the day from morning to morning , whereas John , conforming to practice of Normative Judaism , reckons the day from evening to evening " -- J. Morgenstern , " The Reckoning of the Day in the Gospels and in Acts " , Crozer Quarterly , XXXI ( 1949 ) , 232-240 . <p> That was written in 1949 way before Jaubert . Given the new information that has since come to light we only need to modify two points in Morgenstern 's analysis : ( 1 ) the adoption of the pagan Babylonian luni-solar calendar did not take place in Jerusalem in the 4th century BCE . It took place @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ 2 ) all three Synoptic Gospels reflect the Galilean solar calendar and a sunrise-to-sunrise reckoning of the day , but the Synoptics also allude to how days were reckoned in Pharisaic dominated Jerusalem . <p> The John Gospel , written not by the John ben Zebedee of Galilee who had no formal education ( Acts 4:13 ) , but an eloquent and educated John from Judea with connections to the elite circles and the high priest , is said to have been written to fill in certain blanks in the Synoptics . That explains why so much that is in John is not in the Synoptics . But the most important difference is that the Synoptics do not mention that Passover for the Pharisees the year Jesus was killed was a day later than Passover for Galileans and for Jesus . There can be no question then that this John wanted non-Jewish readers to understand that Galilean Jews and Pharisees were at total odds when it came to the calendar and how days should be reckoned . <p> In article 15649 I wrote : " In article 15627 Tory wrote @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of the pagan Babylonian-Jewish luni-solar calender in the Gospels by Jesus or his followers , nor the ... more

@@2907754 <p> Chapman , Kansas , in Dickinson county , is 72 miles West of Topeka , Kansas ( center to center ) and 90 miles North of Wichita , Kansas . Presently it 's a town of about 1,400 people consisting of retirees , civil service workers and army personnel , with Fort Riley only 15 miles away . The area around is a farming community of wheat , milo , corn , cattle , and hogs . <p> Historical vintage photos from Chapman 's distant past include three from the WSU Archives Library.View #1 is of Main Street in 1907 ; View #2 is an undated street scene , looking South ; and View #3 , an undated example of a city business of that era . <p> In more recent history , on the evening of June 11 , 2008 a 1/2 mile wide tornado swept through Chapman . The tornado moved from the southwest side of town , through the central business district and then out of town . One person was killed and about a hundred other people suffered non-life-threatening injuries . Over 60 homes were @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ damage , including the loss of three churches and all of the school buildings in town as well as the Education Center . A downtown Chapman medical office , 413 N. Marshall was offered by the Abilene Memorial Hospital , and it was used as the Temporary District Office . In September of 2009 , construction was completed on the new Education Center/District Office pictured in View #4 . Many photos and videos before damages and after restoration efforts can be found variously online . <p> The Kansas Auto Racing Museum is located at the base of the beautiful Flint Hills of Central Kansas one-half mile south at Exit 286 off Interstate 70 in the small town of Chapman . A nice place to visit , it is Kansas newest tourist attraction , and may be seen as View #5 . The 21-acre museum complex is the doorway into the local community . Chapman boasts of being the home of astronaut Joe Engle , and the museum is also the launch point for the Joe Engle Chapman Historic Trail Walk . The trail walk enables visitors to enjoy a combination @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ 3.6 miles and includes visits to two historic sites on the National Registry . <p> The museum is home to the first NASCAR trophy . The first NASCAR event was won by Jim Roper of Halstead , Kansas on June 17th , 1949 at Charlotte Speedway . The museum is also home to the first NHRA trophy which held its first national event in Great Bend , Kansas in 1955 . The first NHRA trophy is also on display at the Kansas Auto Racing Museum . The first NHRA event was won by Paul Flynn of Abilene , Kansas . The Kansas Auto Racing Museum also features restored race cars from seven different eras , video Play Stations , rare film footage , photographs and its own private viewing theatre for race film highlights throughout the Midwest . <p> Some race cars to see at the museum are visible in View #6 , View #7 , View #8 , and View #9 . The Kansas Auto Racing Museum is open Monday through Saturday from 9 to 5 and Sundays by appointment only . Tel : 785-922-6642 <p> The one thing @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ the founding Irish settlers that lives on in the hearts of the volunteers who have come together to demonstrate the innate goodness that rises up when faced with a tragedy such as this . They met with a challenge , but remain determined . They will rebuild . After all , they are the Fighting Irish ! 
@@2907755 <p> There were many men in the RAF with the surname of Dean , inevitably , as also a famous footballer was called " Dixie " Dean , so they also became known . There are many Dixie Deans in the RAF . Some served in Greece and some in Malta , some elsewhere . <p> Here are two stories about some remarkable men of the RAF.One wrote a beautiful poem called Well Meet Again . There is a postscript where his widow could not attend his funeral due to i 'll health . <p> The other is one who was famous as an RAF Escaper from P.O.W. camp and quite a legend in the RAF . <p> Both served and fought their own war . <p> Both were remarkable men and made Britain proud to have such men fighting in Royal Air Force blue . <p> Here are their stories : <p> Sergeant James ( Dixie ) Deans MBE was a founder memberand first President of the RAF Ex-POW Association . He also masterminded a powerful intelligence gathering network . Dixie earned the eternal gratitude of thousands of POWs for @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ the latter days of Hitler 's Germany he guided 2,000 fellow POWs to freedom through war-torn Germany.James ' Dixie ' Deans ( 1913 18 February 1989 ) was a RAF Sergeant and World War II bomber pilot shot down in 1940 who became a renowned prisoner of war Camp Leader. 1 <p> Deans spoke perfect German and when captured commanded his fellow POWs as the elected Camp Leader , gaining the respect and trust of both prisoners and German captors alike . In 1945 he guided 2,000 Allied POWs across Europe in what was known as the ' Long March ' . <p> On 10 September 1940 Deans ( of 77 Squadron ) took off from Linton-on-Ouse in a Whitley bomber to attack Bremen . His aircraft was hit by flak and crash landed at Venebrugge ( Overijssel ) , ENE of Zwolle , Holland . <p> Warrant Officer Deans was imprisoned first at Stalag Luft I , then moved to Stalag Luft III , where as camp leader held meetings with the Germans on behalf of the NCO POWs . <p> He was then transferred to Stalag Luft VI @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ he set up covert intelligence gathering networks and the use of radios built in the camps obtained through bribery of selected guards . This enabled the POWs to keep up to date with events from the BBC . He was also responsible for helping to organise the passing of secret information to MI9 via specially coded letters . <p> In March 1945 , Deans took charge of 2,000 POWs on a month-long march across Poland and Germany in what became known as one of the ' Long Marches ' to Stalag XI-B at Fallingbostel . <p> From here Deans and the thousands of POWs were marched north-east towards Lnbeck . Deans took charge of the daily details of survival on the march and bullied the Germans left in charge for food , transport for the sick , and for better overnight accommodation . He also demanded that the German Commandant Oberst Ostmann allow him to set off to warn the approaching British armies of the POW columns ahead . He made contact with the British Army and on returning guided his men to safety where he accepted Oberst Ostmann 's @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ found work as an executive officer at the London School of Economics , until he retired in 1977 . Shortly after the war Deans was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis , which he fought for the rest of his life . Deans was awarded the MBE . <p> Deans was a founder member and first President of the RAF Ex-POW Association . <p> Edward J Tracey wrote ( 3 Jan 2009 ) : In Cornelius Ryan 's book The Last Battle the portion on Dixie Deans concludes : <p> " Good-bye , Colonel Ostmann , " said Deans . " Good-bye , Mr. Deans , " said Ostmann . " I hope we meet again . " Then Deans repeated " Ten-shun ! " and Ostmann and his guards marched into the British POW compound . <p> Is it known if Messrs . Deans and Ostmann ever did meet again ? In April 2010 Cal Younger , editor of The Kriegie wrote " I am almost certain that Dixie and Ostmann never met again . " He died on 18th February 1989 at the age of 76 after a 50 year @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ more precisely , Normanton ) Airfield was home to over two thousand men and women during the Second World War , a population that dwarfed the surrounding villages , drawn from many parts of the world . The young air crews flew out night after night , and many failed to return . <p> These two poems were written by Derrick " Dixie " Dean and Pilot Officer John McGee , airmen serving at RAF Bottesford during the Second World War , and were displayed recently in Bottesford Parish Church . We are grateful to Mrs Viv Finch for showing them to us and allowing us to reproduce them as displayed . <p> We regret that we have not been able to contact the poets or their families , though we understand that Mr Dean still visits Bottesford with his wife . It would be wonderful to hear from them or to learn about them and their wartime expoits . We also hope they will forgive us posting their poems on this site . <p> The interment of Mr Derrick ( Dixie ) Dean 's ashes took take place on @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ , Bottesford . Sadly , his wife Audrey was unable to attend . However , family members were there with representatives from the British Legion and the Armed Services , the Parish Council , Roseland Group , Bottesford Community Heritage Group and Bottesford residents . <p> Here is another , Dixie Dean . Squadron Leader Ernest Henry ' Dixie ' Dean , RAF no. 39718 he was a Biplane fighter ace of 33 Squadron , later led by Pat Pattle , the top scoring RAF ace . Again , like the ... more

@@2907758 <p> Just listen to this sound recording of an interview with Battle of Britain top scoring pilot James Harry " Ginger " Lacey:It says everything about what the Battle of Britain meant to the pilots who fought it , both then and now . <p> He describes what it felt like on 501 Hurricane Squadron losing around 17 men during the Battle of Britain period as the most losses borne by any fighter Sqn in that period . He remarks what it felt like sharing a room with 4 beds for Sergeants of 501 Sqn and realising as the weeks went by at Gravesend , that there was only him left of the original occupants of those beds and wondering when it was his bed that would have a new occupant , the other 3 having , in some cases , 3 owners during that eternal summer of the Battle of Britain 1940 . <p> I can not do justice to how important this interview is for how honest it is and straight talking also . Please listen for an hour , make time as it is as important as @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ how it was , straight from the words of a man who was there and one of the more experienced men in that battle . Which is why he survived , he says although shot down on 9 occasions during those months , here and when based at Kenley also . <p> He covers the break down of Officers and Seargeants segregation , forced by this Battle of Britain , which changed class and status cults forever postwar in the services for the better , as far as Aircrew were concerned , that is . <p> He also desribes combats and why people thought they were like Gods and would not let them buy drinks in the pubs , in grattitude for fighting to keep them safe below . There are some jokes about this the pilots played on watching WAAFs and people as they came out of shelters at Kenley , worth listening to also . <p> He talks very eloquently in answering the questions that , I for one , would not dare have asked Tom Neil , Billy Drake or Bob Foster in the period that I @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ it felt like , why he thinks he survived and his feelings when shooting down the 18 or so Me109s which he did in the Hurricane , which , as he says , postwar revisionists try to say was not as good a fighter as the Me109E . He says he proved them wrong and that there was noithing wrong or inferior in the Hurricane . This from a man who had 1000 hours as a flying instructor pre-war before becoming operational in WW2 . After completion of training Pilot Officer Hardy joined the newly-reformed 234 Squadron at Leconfield on 6th November 1939 ( The squadron was reformed on 20th August ) . The squadron , equipped with Blenheims , Battles and Gauntlets , flew on coastal patrols until it received Spitfire Mark Is , which it took to Church Fenton in May 1940 on @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Cornwall on 18th June 1940 , and then to Middle Wallop in Hampshire on 14th August 1940 . At around 18.30 hours on 15th August 1940 , the squadron was in combat with enemy fighters off Swanage . During the melee , Richards Spitfire Mk I ( N3277 ) was severely damaged . He force landed at Cherbourg and was made a P.O.W. His aircraft was captured intact by the Germans.While interned , Richard received promotion to Flying Officer on 6th November 1940 , and a year later promotion to Flight Lieutenant . @@2907769 <p> Peter Pease of 603 Sqn was killed in action in the single handed attack on the large bomber formation , picked off by the escorting 109s . He died around 5 minutes past 3 , a few minutes ago from this post time , exactly 71 years ago . <p> Men like him fought for Britain and laid down their lives in sacrifice for her sake . We will remember him and his generation , few remain with us in 2011 and these we also remember today . <p> Below is a snapshot op Peter and his young life cut short by his sacrifice , a sacrifice worthy of the VC as mentioned in the book , The Most Dangerous Enemy . Peter was the friend of Richard Hillary of 603 Sqn who had been shot down in flames on September 5th by Helmut Bode , the fighter ace . He was recovering in hospital when he had a dream , seeing Peter die in his dream , and later he got news that this is what happened . <p> Below is Peters short life story ; /O A.Peter @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Richard Pease from Richmond , Yorkshire . He studied at Eton and Cambridge Universities until he joined the R.A.F. at the beginning of the war . He joined No 603 Squadron in July 1940 at Dyce near Aberdeen . He was friends with Richard Hillary and D.M.Crook . On the 30th of July 1940 he was credited with a half share in a He 111 . On the 10th of August 1940 the Squadron moved to Hornchurch into the thick of the action . A.P.Pease shot down a Bf 109 on the on the 3rd of September 1940 in the same action as his friend , Richard Hillary was wounded . He had a lucky escape on the 7th of September 1940 , his Spitfire was damaged in action over London and he made a forced landing at Hornchurch . A.Peter Pease was shot down and killed in his Spitfire I ( X4324 ) on the 15th of September 1940 at 15:05hrs by a Bf 109 over Kingswood in Kent while he was attacking a formation of He 111 's . He crashed a few miles South East of Maidstone @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ celebrated all-round sportsman Max Woosnam : in the 1920s he was captain of Manchester City , played tennis at Wimbledon and led the Davis Cup team , and scored a century at Lords . Denise was a debutante in 1936 , and was presented to Edward VIII at a Buckingham Palace garden party : although she had written a novel , she was expected to aim for nothing but marriage . In the summer of 1938 she joined the War Offices recruiting branch of the ATS . <p> While stationed in Cheshire , she met Peter Pease at a night skating party : " a bit of glamour in a not very glamorous situation . This tall figure unwrapped itself from the car , and it was Peter : and that was that . " Pease Eton , Cambridge , the eldest son of a distinguished Yorkshire family was handsome , gifted , a winner of academic prizes , full of promise . They were quickly engaged : " Everything happened quickly in the war : you saw everything as through a telescope at the wrong end . " <p> @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Essex , and soon afterwards Pease was posted from 603 Squadron in Edinburgh , to Hornchurch . Instead of delight , Denise felt foreboding , having watched , day after day , young pilots shot down in dogfights . Her fiance lasted only 14 days : he was killed on Battle of Britain day , Sunday September 15 . " I was on duty at Vange , but so many planes came down all the time that nobody had any track : it was nearly a fortnight before I got a telegram from his parents , asking me to come to his funeral . That was the first I 'd heard . Ones world had ended . " They had known each other for just five months . <p> Peters last letter to her had asked her to visit " our Mr Hillary " in hospital . " I thought , with ones world over , that I could go and see this chap whom I 'd never met . He was indescribably burnt . And you see from pictures how extraordinarily good-looking he had been . <p> " I do n't  @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ pit of despair he suffered . And he had lost his best friends . " <p> In The Last Enemy , Hillary recalls his visiting mother , Edwyna , saying , " You should be glad this has happened to you . Too many people told you how attractive you were , and you believed them . You were well on the way to becoming something of a cad . Now you will find out who your real friends are , I did . " <p> Denises warmth and sincerity , wrote Hillary , did more to help his recovery than all the expert medical attention he was getting . " For me she was the very spirit of courage . " She had an inner beauty , a serenity , " a perfection of carriage and a grace of movement that were strikingly reminiscent of Peter Pease , and when she spoke it might have been Peter speaking " . <p> He was allowed out of the hospital in the afternoons , and would arrive at Denises house in Eaton Place , London , to find her curled on @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ war , of life and death ; but she was " a beautiful ghost " , locked into her mourning , bound for eternity , she believed , to Peters memory . <p> Hillary hoped for romance , and Hillarys mother , whom Denise called " Marmee " loved her like a daughter ; but as Denise says , emotionally she " went into deep-freeze " for several years , before meeting the man she married . <p> In memory of Peter Pease , killed in a solo , head-on attack on a Luftwaffe bomber formation . Knew the odds were stacked against him and was killed by Bf109s . Men in actions like this were worthy of ... more <p> Dear Paul , This is beautifully written ! I am a member of Trinity College ( 1955 ) , as was Richard . I write about him , especially the children of Tarfside . I should like to correspond . Best wishes , ... more <p> Hi Richard , Thank you . My E Mail is p.73davies@sky.com Also I run a website over on Facebook which is Battle of @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ We remember Richard Hillary and ... more

@@2907773 <p> The above post copied data from another slightly erroneous account , nearly correct.This is the nearest full explanation of the tragic losses in action during September 5th 1940 of both 41 Sqn Ldr . Hood nad his experienced Flt . Lt. J. T. Webster : <p> CommentsThis Squadron has for many years been of great interest to me . A serving Officer during the Battle of Britain is often misrepresented in many books and histories on the subject of the Battle of Britain . The young Officer was F/Lt . John Terence Webster , DFC , RAF . He was tragically killed in a mid-air collision on the 05th September 1940 , with his friend and Squadron CO , S/Ldr.H.R.L.Hood , RAF . This is the part that is wrong . Yes F/Lt . " Terry " Webster , DFC , RAF was most certainly killed in a mid-air collision . But it was with F/Lt.R.E.Lovett , DFC , RAF , of number 73(F) Squadron.The action took place very near my home , and long and extensive research has gone into these deaths of our Nations hero 's . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ was hit in the leading edge of the wing of his Hurricane . In peeling off &amp; away from the danger he collided with a Spitfire climbing into the attack ( Webster ) . Lovett baled out , landing by parachute at Rawreth , Essex . Poor Webster 's Spitfire disintigrated throwing wreckage from Bonvilles Farm , on the Southend A127 Arterial road , across the fields , the smashed fuselage coming to earth at Nevendon , Wickford , his parachute was found close by in a Farmers field etc . Young Webster 's body was recovered from beside the A127 Arterial Road , and removed to Billericay Hospital 's mortuary . I have a copy of the death certificate . A rare find in 73(F) Squadrons ORB tells of Lovett 's collision with Webster 's Spitfire R6635 - EB-M . All RAF losses for the day can be accounted for , with the exception of S/Ldr.H.R.L . Hoods aircraft . No wreckage has ever been found or a body , and the only unidentified aircraft known to records is a British Fighter seen diving into the Channel 100 yards @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Hood ? . We probably will never know , but its a very strong possibility . F/Lt.R.E.Lovett 's Hurricane fell flat minus a wing and fell at Nevendon Road Sewrage works ( as is today ) farmland during the war and known as " Nevendon Hall " . Tragically this young Officer lost his young life two days later over Stock , Billericay , Essex . His Hurricane after combat with Bf110s impacted into the ground in a small field behind the Roman Catholic Church , ( A school at the time ) . A memorial plaque was erected within the church by my friend and son of a 41 ( F ) Squadron veteran of the Battle of Britain , Mr. Morrough- Ryan . Near my own home when knew development of the area presented itself . A new road was dedicated to F/Lt . John Terence Webster 's memory . Always simply loved being known as " Terry " , his widow Peta wanted " Terence Webster Road " , turnings off " Terence Webster Road " , honour S/Ldr.Hoods memory , and P/O . John MacKenzie , @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ which forms the centre of the Squadron badge , bestowed on the Squadron by the Mayor of St.Omer for service carried out by the Squadrons SE5A 's during the First World War when the Squadron was stationed there . I dedicate this message to Terry 's memory , his widow Peta and their only son John.There is also a small memorial placed at the edge of one of the gardens adjacent to " Terence Webster Road , unveilled by Terry 's widow &amp; Son John . <p> Postscript ; John or Terry Webster , as he was called , shot down at least 12 aircraft plus many others unconfirmed or probable . Some list him with 14 victories . <p> Had he not been killed then , he could well have ended with more than Lock , McKellar , Lacey or Frantisek . <p> May he rest in peace now that the true facts are shown , thanks to the site below and John Williams who has tried to put the record straight for many years , correcting the myth of the collision with Hood and Webster Any one with @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ <p> I wanted to add a little more to why Terry Webster of 41 Sqn deserves a mention . Here is part of the great mans story ; from publicans son to respected fighter ace : In regards to Terry Webster , the ... more

@@2907775 <p> Elected king of Hungary in 1458 after a series of foreign rulers , Matthias Corvinus reigned for 32 years in what became a glorious period in Hungarian history . Matthias won a reputation as a crusader against the Ottomans . He conquered Moravia , Silesia , Lusatia , Vienna , Styria , Carinthia , and Carniola successes largely due to his establishment of a standing army . Known as the Black Army of Hungary , it consisted of thousands of paid soldiers , including Hungarians as well as mercenaries from where ? <p> The first European usage of the arquebus in large ratios was in Hungary under king Matthias Corvinus ( 1458-1490 ) . Every thirdsoldier in the Black Army of Hungary had an arquebus . <p> The Black Army ( Hungarian : Fekete sereg , pronounced ' f ? k ? t ? ' ? ? r ? g ' Black Legion or Regiment ' possibly named after their black armor panoply , see below ) is in historiography the common name given to the excellent quality of diverse and polyglot military forces serving under the reign of @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of this early standing mercenary army appeared in the era of his father ( John Hunyadi ) in the early 1440s . <p> It is recognized as one of the main standing continental European fighting force not under conscription and its founder King Matthias is often compared to Julius Caesar . Hungary 's Black Army traditionally encompasses the years from 1458 to 1490 . The men of the Black Army fought as well-paid , full-time mercenaries and were purely devoted to the arts of warfare . Most European mercenary armies of the era were conscripted from the general population at times of crisis and soldiers worked as bakers , farmers , brick-makers , etc ... for most of the year . It was an unusually large standing mercenary army for its time , and it conquered parts of Austria , Vienna ( 1485 ) and parts of Moravia . <p> The core of the army originally consisted of 8-10 thousand mercenaries , later increasing to a permanent size of 30,000 men and doubling during invasions . The soldiers were mainly Bohemians , Germans , Serbs , Poles and , from @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Army had an arquebus in the infantry , and every fifth regarding the whole army , which was an unusual ratio at the time . The high price of medieval gunpowder prevented them to raise it any further . The main troops of the army were the infantry , artillery and light and heavy cavalry . The function of the heavy cavalry was to protect the light armored infantry and artillery , while the other corps inflicted random attacks on the enemy . One important victory of the Black Army of Hungary was at the Battle of Breadfield where the Hungarians defeated the Ottomans . The death of Matthias Corvinus meant the end of the " Black Army " , because Vladislaus II was not able to cover the costs of the army . <p> Development of a modern well-organized draftingFrom the first mercenaires to regularly paid soldiersThe term Black Army and its captainsFunding the army to its biggest extentImproving the river fleetUprisings within the Black ArmyBranches , tactics , equipments ... Heavy Cavalry ...... Weaponry ... Light LONG ... and respective captains of the Black Army ... Campaign color codesNotes ... Name variationsSee alsoReferencesExternal links 
@@2907776 <p> The following is posted with full permission from Captain Quixote , author of the original Mischievous Breeze stories which inspired my story . Thank you Captain Quixote ! <p> Twin breezes were born of the famous Mischievous Breeze . The Breeze took a brief look at his offspring and swelled with pride . His offspring seemed to be female in nature , but no less impish in their mind-set than their father . The Breeze smiled a knowing and appreciative smile . He had had his fun stripping girls and women . His daughters , no doubt , were going to do the same to the human males . Before heading off to further his own adventures , he named them Zephyr and Squall . <p> The daughters watched as the Breeze left . The roguish ways he passed on to them soon dominated and their desire to carry on his naughty deeds , albeit on boys , compelled them on to their own adventures . So , onward to their first victim . <p> A boy stood at the corner waiting for the light to change so he @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ taking forever which annoyed him but was very useful to the two breezes . The boy had on a pair of basketball shorts and a tank top . The breezes formulated their course of action and descended on the lad . Zephyr blew his shirt up to keep him a bit occupied . While struggling with his shirt , the boy blushed a little bit at having his torso unexpectedly bared out in public . Passersby chuckled at the struggling lads misfortune with a few girls appreciating the young lads cute upper body . <p> While her sister kept the boy impeded by his own shirt , Squall circled around his shorts . @@2907779 <p> Mob football , a precursor to modern soccer and rugby , emerged in Europe during the Middle Ages . It typically involved an unlimited number of players from neighboring villages . The rules were vague and few . In some versions , any means short of murder could be used to move the ball back and forth . The game likely resembled a riot , and although mob football became an annual tradition in some places , it was frequently banned . According to legend , what was used as the first football ? <p> An illustration of so-called " mob football " <p> Mob football is the name given to some varieties of Medieval football , which emerged in Europe during the Middle Ages . <p> Mob football distinguished itself from other codes by typically having an unlimited number of players and very few rules . By some accounts , any means could be used to move the ball to a goal , as long as it did not lead to manslaughter or murder . These early codes of football were forerunners of modern codes of football such @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ a Roman game similar to modern Rugby Football , may have been introduced to Britannia during the Roman Conquest , although there is no historical evidence to back up this claim . The uncertain origins of these games have attracted explanation by myth and legend . For example , in the UK , some claim that the games started as a celebration of the defeat of the Romans in the 3rd century . The claim also exists that it was first played with the severed head of a Danish ruler of England who had been deposed . <p> Whatever their exact origins may have been , by the Middle Ages these games had generally become annual celebrations and had a tendency to get quite out of hand . Mob football would have more resembled a riot than any of its descendants . The sport usually involved groups of men from two connecting villages ( or two groups from either end of a single village ) fighting to move a ball from one side to the other . The games were so unruly that royal bans were often placed on the @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Edward II of England issued what is believed to be the first royal decree : <p> For as much as there is a great noise in the city caused by huslting over large balls , from which many evils may arrice , what God forbid , we can command and forbid on behalf of the King , on pain of imprisonment , such games to be used in the city in future . <p> Additional photos can be found elsewhere online of recent renowned traditional matches . One website features those below among over one hundred more photos illustrating action at Ashbourne Shrovetide Football in Derbyshire annually such as this in 2009 . Others give great detail about preparations , rituals and results , as well as this video . 
@@2907780 <p> The shock and awe doctrine is a military strategy based on the use of overwhelming force , dominant maneuvers , and staggering displays of power to control an adversary 's perception of the battlefield and quickly destroy its will to fight . Though the doctrine recognizes the need to minimize civilian casualties , it relies on the disruption of water supplies , food production , and other aspects of infrastructure . What historic military campaigns can be said to have operated under similar principles ? <p> According to its original theorists , Shock and Awe renders an adversary unwilling to resist through overwhelming displays of power . Ullman cites the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki as an example of " shock and awe . " <p> Shock and awe , technically known as rapid dominance , is a military doctrine based on the use of overwhelming decisive force , dominant battlefield awareness , dominant maneuvers , and spectacular displays of power to paralyze an adversary 's perception of the battlefield and destroy its will to fight . The doctrine was written by Harlan K. Ullman and James P. @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of the United States in 1996 . <p> Doctrine of rapid dominance <p> Rapid dominance is defined by its authors , Harlan K. Ullman and James P. Wade , as attempting " to affect the will , perception , and understanding of the adversary to fit or respond to our strategic policy ends through imposing a regime of Shock and Awe . " 1 Further , rapid dominance will <p> " impose this overwhelming level of Shock and Awe against an adversary on an immediate or sufficiently timely basis to paralyze its will to carry on . . . to seize control of the environment and paralyze or so overload an adversary 's perceptions and understanding of events that the enemy would be incapable of resistance at the tactical and strategic levels . " 2 <p> Introducing the doctrine in a report to the United States ' National Defense University in 1996 , Ullman and Wade describe it as an attempt to develop a post-Cold War military doctrine for the United States . Rapid dominance and shock and awe , they write , may become a " revolutionary change " @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ information technology is increasingly integrated into warfare. 3 Subsequent U.S. military authors have written that rapid dominance exploits the " superior technology , precision engagement , and information dominance " of the United States. 4 <p> Ullman and Wade identify four vital characteristics of rapid dominance : " near total or absolute knowledge and understanding of self , adversary , and environment ; rapidity and timeliness in application ; operational brilliance in execution ; and ( near ) total control and signature management of the entire operational environment . " 5 Shock and awe is most consistently used by Ullman and Wade as the effect which rapid dominance seeks to impose upon an adversary . It is the desired state of helplessness and lack of will . It can be induced , they write , by direct force applied to command and control centers , selective denial of information and dissemination of disinformation , overwhelming combat force , and rapidity of action . <p> The doctrine of rapid dominance has evolved from the concept of " decisive force . " Ullman and Wade enumerate the elements between the two concepts @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ size , scope , speed , casualties , and technique .

@@2907789 <p> April 10 , 1878 - Ford County Globe " At ten o'clock last night . City Marshal Edward Masterson , discovered that a cowboy who was working for Obum of Kansas City , named Jack Wagner , was carrying a six-shooter contrary to the City Ordinance . Wagner was at the time under the influence of liquor , but quietly gave up the pistol . The Marshal gave it to some of Wagner 's friends for safe keeping and stepped out into the street . No sooner had he done so than Wagner ran out after him pulling another pistol , which the Marshal had not observed . The Marshal saw him coming and turned upon Wagner and grabbed hold of him . <p> Wagner shot Marshal Masterson at once through the abdomen , being so close to him that the discharge set the Marshal 's clothes on fire . Marshal Masterson then shot Wagner . <p> About this time a man named Walker got mixed up in the fight . He , it appears , was boss herder for Obum , and Wagner was working under him . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ and his right arm was twice broken . <p> Marshal Masterson walked across the street to George M. Hoover 's saloon , where after telling that he was shot , he sank to the floor . He was immediately removed to his room , where in half an hour he expired . <p> Walker and Wagner were nearly all night insensible , and none thought that either of them could live through the night . However , morning has come and neither are dead ; both are in a very precarious condition and their chances for recovery very small . <p> The city is in mourning ; every door is draped with crape ; business is entirely suspended till after the funeral of Marshal Masterson , which will take place at two o'clock p. m. , and will be attended by everybody in the city . Marshal Masterson will be buried in the Military Cemetery , at Fort Dodge . " <p> April 13 , 1878 - Dodge City Times " Died . In this city , on Tuesday , April 9th , in the 26th year of his age @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ subject of this sketch was born in Henryville , Canada East , on September 22d , 1852 , and removed to Wichita , Kansas with his parents in 1869 , where he continued to reside until attaining his majority when he left his home and became one of the first inhabitants of this city . <p> In June 5 , 1877 he accepted the appointment of Assistant Marshal , and in the December , 1877 , having displayed marked adaptability for the position , he was promoted to the Marshalship , in the discharge of the duties of which he continued until his unfortunate death . <p> Possessed of a geniality of temperament , a kindness of heart and a richness of personal bravery , he had many warm friends and admirers . <p> As an officer he followed the dictation of duty , striving at all times for its honest and complete discharge and gaming for himself the dignity and respect that of necessity followed from his determined intrepidity . <p> He died in the service he performed so well , and has added one other to the list @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ , each of his day and generation , but who dead , belong to all time , and whose voices ring down the ages in solemn protest against the reign of violence and blood . " <p> April 9 1876South Dakota A mining camp , called Lead City is born almost overnight when Hank Harney and two brothers , Moses and Fred Manuel , discovered an out-cropping of ore .
