@@2907792 <p> Every garden is amazing . From the smallest container to the most dramatic botanic garden ( such as those listed here ) , gardens help us appreciate the natural beauty around us , amaze us with the diversity that exists in the plant world , and stand testament to the creativity of those whose art consists not of brushes and paints , but of flowers and plants . <p> Whether they stand as symbols of a leaders greatness , as a wealthy mans monument to his love of plants , or as a beautifully cataloged collection of a particular type of plant , the world would be a sad place without its botanic gardens . Here are five of the most dramatic , amazing gardens from around the world . <p> 1 . Musee du Quai Branly Vertical Garden , ParisThe streets in this area of Paris mimic the meandering curves of the Seine , and at the heart of it is the Quai Branly Museum . The building itself is a hodgepodge of shapes , but it is the administrative wing that really draws attention . The four-story @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ from sidewalk to roof in plants . <p> Designed by botanist and landscape designer Patrick Blanc , the garden comprises 15,000 plants . With 170 species represented , the garden is an amazing spectacle of urban vertical gardening that celebrates biodiversity . Plants included in Blancs design include heuchera , ferns , ivy , grasses , sedges , mosses , liverwort and bergenia . <p> The patented system Blanc designed to support the garden ( and others he s designed ) is constructed of heavy-duty felt attached to a strong plastic backing . The felt and plastic support plant roots and provide a medium for water and nutrients to reach the plants . The entire thing is supported by a metal frame that holds the plants off of the facade of the building to reduce the potential for damage from plant roots . A drip irrigation system at the top of the wall runs constantly , bathing the plant roots in moisture and nutrients . <p> 2 . The Lost Gardens of Heligan , Cornwall , UKFrom the mid-1700 's through the early 20th century , the Tremayne family of @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ estate . After losing the majority of its gardening staff in World War I , the gardens fell into a state of disrepair that only continued and worsened through the second World War and thereafter . The gardens became overgrown and neglected , and any of its former splendor was lost in the mess that remained . That changed , though , in the 1990 's when a descendant of the Tremayne family inherited the estate . Upon looking around , the family realized that there was beauty amid the chaos , and undertook the enormous task of bringing the gardens back to their former glory . <p> The magnificent Heligan Gardens are designed in what is known as the " gardenesque " style , which means that different parts of the garden have entirely different moods and focuses . The gardens include several very old rhododendrons and camellias , an Italian-style garden , a large vegetable garden , Europes only productive pineapple pit , and " The Jungle , " which is filled with sub-tropical tree ferns . The gardens are now open to the public , and the @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of the gardens most beloved features . <p> 3 . The Nong Nooch Botanical Garden , ThailandThis amazing , 500-acre garden was originally destined to be a fruit plantation . Instead , the owners decided to plant tropical plants and flowers . The result is nothing short of magnificent . <p> The 500 acres are divided among several themed gardens and display gardens , including a cactus and succulent garden , a French garden , a garden inspired by Stonehenge , a display garden featuring variegated plants , an orchid and bromeliad display garden , and " Butterfly Hill " which features tropical plants that attract butterflies . Nong Nooch is also home to a vast collection of cycads that boasts at least one member of every single cycad species on the planet . <p> The garden is arranged geographically , grouping Arctic and alpine plants together by continent , as well as by botanical association ( so related plants within a specific region are grouped together . ) All together , the garden showcases thousands of botanical taxa within its 20 collections . <p> The garden also strives to @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ terrain of Alpine regions . A " Geology Walk " explores rocks of Norway , and signs throughout the garden help visitors appreciate the uniqueness of alpine plants . <p> 5 . Rikugien Garden , TokyoThe work " rikugien " means " six poems garden " in Japanese . This breathtaking garden in Tokyo features gardens with 88 scenes that bring famous places in Japan and China , historical references , and poems to life . <p> Rikugien Garden was constructed in the late 1600s through early 1700s by Yanagisawa Yoshiyasu , with permission from the fifth shogun Tokugawa Tsunayoshi . Some of its most popular features include a serene pond and islands , teahouses , and forested areas . In all , the garden is home to over 6,000 trees , particularly maples , camellias , magnolias , and azaleas . <p> Gardens like these are wonderful not only for the pleasure they provide just by being there , but by the inspiration they can provide for our own gardens . They also open our eyes to the diversity of plants on our planet and the creative ways we 've @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ multi-platform media destination devoted to the environment and dedicated to helping people understand how humans impact the planet and how to live a more environmentally sustainable lifestyle . Its two robust websites , planetgreen.com and TreeHugger.com , offer original , inspiring , and entertaining content related to how we can evolve to live a better , brighter future . Planet Green is a division of Discovery Communications . 
@@2907793 <p> Another kind of milestone occurred in 1906 when the San Francisco earthquake brought havoc to much of the Bay Area . The refinery incurred relatively limited damage , which included the collapse of several brick chimneys , the shattering of a fire wall , the springing of some tank seams , and the snapping of a wharf line . In 1907 , the refinery made a particularly important contribution to Standard Oil Co . ( California ) , which had taken over PCO 's operations a year earlier , when it developed Zerolene motor oil . Howard French , an early refinery employee , recalled his part in the original formulation of Zerolene , saying : " I 'd watch a batch of it the way a chef watches soup , and somehow I 'd know when it was just right . Everybody said , ' You ca n't do this or that with California crude . ' But whatever it was you could n't do , we did it . That was great oil ! " Also known as Polarine , Zerolene oil soon achieved market success from @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Far East where it was marketed . <p> The refinery 's early years yielded steady growth . One important contributor to its growth was the ready availability of crude oil from the Southern California fields . The refinery 's access to plentiful crude grew during the 1910s with the development of the Midway field and others in the San Joaquin Valley . By 1906 , Richmond was one of the largest refineries in the world , as crude runs rose to an average of about 25,000 barrels a day . By 1914 , as the world was on the brink of war , the output had reached 65,000 barrels a day . <p> Nice day today in the desert . Expecting 80mph winds later t is afternoon . @@2907797 <p> In 1838 , members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints from Caldwell County , Missouri , founded a fraternal organization known as the Danites . Though it is believed that the Danites operated as a vigilante group during the Mormon War , historians disagree as to the exact nature and scope of the organization . Nevertheless , the Danites and their alleged atrocities have become part of Mormon folklore and were even featured in the first novel starring which fictional detective ? <p> 1 " The Battle of Crooked River , " by C.C.A . @@2907799 <p> While we are all living , and residing here on this planetary universally connected light matrix of our physical realm by our gravitational infrared densities and existence here and thereof our being encompassed wholly and by only all spectrum and spectral physical densities that is what is for us to live our lives as then thus our being and serving as being a part of this universally connected clock that has been pre set for us to be the clock 's components . By ( Dr. ) Will P. Wilson August 03 , 2015 posted on the http : //www.APFN.org - Message News Board LONG ... <p> John Worrell Keely ( 1837-1898 ) of Philadelphia was a carpenter and mechanic who announced in 1872 that he had discovered a new principle for power production . The vibrations of a simple tuning fork had given him the idea , and the means to tap etheric energy . <p> At this time most physicists believed that all of space was filled with an elusive fluid called the " luminiferous ether " . Experiments were conducted to measure the properties of this @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ early decades of the 20th century the ether idea faded away . Physicists finally realized that the reason they could n't detect the ether or measure its properties was simply that it was n't there . But more importantly , the old reasons they had given for thinking it was there turned out to be resolved by the theory of relativity . Today the luminiferous ether is seldom even mentioned in textbooks . <p> Keely persuaded a dozen engineers and capitalists to invest in the idea , forming the Keely Motor Company in New York in 1872 . Soon he had capital of one million dollars , primarily from wealthy New York and Philadelphia businessmen . He used the money to buy materials necessary for building a motor based on his theories . <p> Soon he had constructed an etheric generator , which he demonstrated to amazed audiences in 1874 in Philadelphia . Keely blew into a nozzle for half a minute , then poured five gallons of tap water into the same nozzle . After some fine adjustments the pressure gage indicated pressures of 10,000 pounds per square inch @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ water had been disintegrated and a mysterious vapor had been liberated in the generator , capable of powering machinery . <p> One spectator at a Keely demonstration described the power of the machine . " Great ropes were torn apart , iron bars broken in two or twisted out of shape , bullets discharged through twelve inch planks , by a force which could not be determined . " <p> Keely predicted his discovery would make other forms of power obsolete . A quart of water would be enough to send a train from Philadelphia to San Francisco and back . A gallon would propel a steamship from N. Y. to Liverpool and back . " A bucket of water has enough of this vapor to produce a power sufficient to move the world out of its course . " <p> - Keely and the board of directors of the Keely Motor Company . - Keely lived comfortably , as befitted the president of a company , but not extravagently . To his credit , he plowed most of the invested money into research equipment and tools . He did @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ own apparatus . He was not willing to entrust his secret to those who could not or would not understandespecially physicists and engineers . Skeptics noted that the equipment could never be made to work as it was supposed to unless Keely was present . - LONG ... - John Worrell Keely photographed in his laboratory in 1889 . The Bettmann Archive . - - Keely 's hydro-vacuo engine . <p> The work went slowly . To keep up the spirits of stockholders Keely staged occasional public demonstrations . These were masterpieces of showmanship . He demonstrated a marvelous machine , a " vibratory engine " or " hydro-pneumatic pulsating vacuo-engine . " It was a work of the machinist 's art , made of gleaming brass and copper . The engine was attached to another machine called a " liberator , " a complicated array of brass wires , tubes and tuning forks . <p> Keely explained that he was tapping a " latent force " of naturethe vibratory energy of the ether . We can blame that idea on the physicists . Keely often used a harmonica , @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ his machines . Some said that it was worth the price of being duped to hear the eloquent language Keely used wo explain his theory . Keely was said to have considerable musical knowledge and talent . Skeptics suggested that these musical tones were a signal to a hidden confederate to activate the secret trickery and mechanisms that made the miracles happen . <p> A central idea of Keely 's theory of nature was the notion that musical tones could resonate with atoms , or with the ether itself . He even drew this musical chart to help people understand the finer points of this theory . There are those today who use this as evidence that Keely was far ahead of his time , anticipating the theory of quantum mechanics . The man with a new idea is a crank , until the idea succeeds . Mark Twain . <p> Biographers have described Keely as a " mechanical experimenter " , " inventor and imposter " , " professor of perfidy " , " swindler " , and " scandalous scamp " . Keely 's lack of formal scientific @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ deter Keely himself from grandly proclaiming his theories as " scientific " . <p> Keely expounded his ideas using an elaborate theory of the " etheric force " , spiced with eloquently profound terms such as : " sympathetic equilibrium , quadrupole negative harmonics , etheric disintegration " . His backers were duly impressed . He looked with condescending pity on those who appeared not to understand . - <p> With our present knowledge no definition can be given of the latent force , which , possessing all the conditions of attraction and repulsion associated with it , is free of magnetism . If it is a condition of electricity , robbed of all electrical phenomena , or a magnetic force , repellant to the phenomena associated with magnetic development , the only philosophical conclusion I can arrive at is that this indefinable element is the soul of matter . J. W. Keely . <p> Some disillusioned stockholders withdrew their support as Keely 's experiments suffered repeated delays . Keely declared he 'd already proven his theory could be implemented for useful purposes , and he made vast claims for @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ energy sources . But he resisted investor 's demands that he produce some marketable product . Stockholders were not happy with Keely 's insistence that more experimentation was needed to " perfect " the machines . Fortunately , when nearing bankruptcy , Keely acquired a wealthy backer , Mrs. Clara S. J. Bloomfield-Moore , the widow of a Philadelphia paper manufacturer . <p> - Glass flask containing weights that Keely claimed could be moved up or down by striking the zither strings which activated the " globe Liberator " . A wire connects the globe liberator to the flask . <p> - Test of the sympatheticforce of vitalized disks . <p> The Keely Motor Stuck Again.Keely 's first week of solitary confinement with his motor for the purpose of " focalizing and adjusting the vibrators , " has resulted , not in the single revolution which is to demonstrate his final triumph , but in another postponement . We learn from one of our contemporaries that the stockholders met in Philadelphia on the 26th , and waited with great excitement for a report from Keely . He sent word that @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ he was too busy to leave it even for a moment , and that they could fix a date for exhibition on or before April 10 . Then the stockholders separated , cheerful and hopeful as usual . Scientific American , April 5 , 1884 , p. 213 . <p> She advanced him over $100,000 for expenses and promised him a salary of $2,500 per month . She became active in promoting Keely in journals and books and in seeking scientists who might validate his claims . She suggested that Keely share his secret with Edison or Tesla to hasten its development , but he refused . He did agree that scientists at least be allowed to observe the demonstrations . <p> E. Alexander Scott , an electrical engineer , witnessed such a demonstration . When Keely showed him the etheric power causing a weight to rise and fall in a closed flask of water , Scott was unimpressed . Keely used the sound from a zither to activate the globe liberator which then supposedly transmitted the etheric force through a wire to the water container . Scott suspected the @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of water pressure could cause it to rise or fall , just as a Cartesian diver . The wire , he guessed , was a hollow tube transmitting air pressure to the water chamber . To counter this suggestion , Keely cut a ways into the wire with a file to prove it solid . But Moore surreptitiously picked up a scrap piece of similar wire in the workshop and later found that it did have a very fine , hollow center . <p> Other demonstrations showed the etheric force to be great enough to lift large weights . It could also fire Keely 's " vaporic gun " , demonstrated at Sandy Hook , Long Island . <p> Keely Nearing the EndIt was announced from Philadelphia on the 17th of March that the Keely motor was practically completed . All the workmen had been discharged , and Mr. Keely was immediately to begin " focalizing and adjusting the vibrators " a delicate operation but easy for himand as soon as he obtained " one perfect revolution , though even so slow , " the great invention would be complete @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ newspapers and quite a flutter among the stock holders and directors , who have been for several years investing money to back up this nineteenth century discoverer of " perpetual motion " . It is difficult , indeed , to consider seriously this alleged invention , or justly characterize the inventor , who , in this age , not only assumes to get something out of nothing , but would hide all his methods and processes and affect more than the mystery of the alchemists of the early ages . Yet it is a serious matter to those who have been sinking their money therein . Now , however , we seem at last to have reached the " beginning of the end , " and the attention of the investors can , at an early day , be " focalized " on their profit and loss accounts . Scientific American , March 25 , 1884 , p. 196 . <p> - The secrets of Keely 's laboratory , published in The New York Journal . <p> The Scientific American magazine followed Keely 's career with some amazement and amusement @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ demonstrations they had witnessed could easily have been produced with hidden sources of compressed air . <p> Keely continued this research for fourteen years , occasionally staging demonstrations to placate impatient stockholders . Mrs. Moore was concerned by Alexander Scott 's negative report , and by dismissive and unkind articles in newspapers and magazines . So she sought a second opinion from physicist Prof. W. Lascelles-Scott , from England . @@2907803 <p> The term " strength " is used to often on this site without defining what type of strength people are referring to . Really understanding the different types of strength is central to developing as a successful thrower . <p> The first distinction is to really understand the difference between strength and power . Javelins are not thrown with strength but with power . <p> This simple question illustrates the difference between strength and power rather well . " Which releases more energy 10lbs of coal or 10lbs of TNT high explosive ? " <p> The answer surprisingly is the 10lbs of coal ! <p> It is the relationship to TIME that dictates the kind of work that energy does . Strength requires time . Power requires as little time as possible . The reason that the TNT can do so much damage is that it only takes a fraction of a second to release it 's energy . Where as the coal may take an hour to burn . <p> Back to the javelin . . . <p> With weight training it takes about 0.3 - 0.4 of @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ But it takes only between 0.16 - 0.18 seconds to throw a javelin . <p> So no one can get to put their maximum possible muscular force behind a javelin when throwing it . ( Force requires resistance and time to build . ) Your body can only contract to about 50% of your max possible force in the time available to throw a javelin - less than 0.18 of a second . <p> This means that at any part of your development as a thrower your absolute strength is important BUT it may not be as important as how fast you can move about 50% of that absolute strength . This kind of 50% of 1rep max strength can be called explosive-strength . This is the beginnings of power , but not the true beast ! Most natural javelin throwers are really good at this explosive-strength . <p> So both maximal strength and explosive-strength are really important . <p> But most of the power that throws a javelin comes from NOT from the muscles but from energy stored in the connective tissue . This now gives us a third @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ bodies ability to absorb and release energy . This is the essence of the javelin throw and why we convert energy from the run-up through the bloc into the throw . This is true power . Max possible force and minimal time . I recall that Jan Zelezny 's throws took less time than any one else . <p> So you can hopefully see that training as a thrower needs to include all of these . <p> Absolute StrengthExplosive StrengthElastic Strength <p> There is a possibility to gradually get stronger as the years go by and becoming more explosive with it . But what will make you a javelin thrower is how you improve your elastic-strength on top of the others . This is why others on this site keep telling people to do medball , ball throwing , bounding etc . <p> There was a post from Nemethjavelins a while back that quotes Jan Zelezny as having a best bench press of 115kg ( 253lbs ) While this is not weak this is by no sense strong . His power was elsewhere . I would guess in Elastic and @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ My advice would be that when ever you train - ask yourself what kind of strength am I trying to develop and why . I think that there should be a flow from absolute strength to explosive strength to elastic strength to release velocity . <p> Lovely post of important points . Minor correction- Zelezny 's pullover was what he referred to for his best lift @ 115k , not bench . That 's a pretty fair lift , but I 've seen some of the top German guys ... more <p> 140k pullover is incredible . What is the point of doing 140k in the pullover if all the upper body has to move is a .8k javelin ? Is there any other reason than trickle down strength/power ? Confidence ... more <p> Zelezny had been a World Top 10 thrower for nearly 20 years . If , you look at 5%/year improvement w/ a 70-75k starting point you can get to a 140k total in a decade pretty easily . In the article where ... more <p> Are there any other methods that these guys used other than @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ to the pullover at greater speeds ? Do you know if they were they doing speed ... more <p> Before I moved to Arizona , Kari Ihalainen was living in Phoenix and would come down to Tucson to work with Esko and some of the U of Arizona throwers . He built this thing that I 'm using in this ... more <p> lots of variety- there are sessions w/ light &amp; fast as well as heavier loads moved slower . Of course , we 're talking about top guys/gals w/ 10 years or more elite level training under their belts . In ... more

@@2907807 <p> As to the origin of this word in the phrase " Three cheers and a tiger , " the following explanation has been given . In 1822 the Boston Light Infantry , under Captain Mackintosh and Lieutenant Robert C. Winthrop , visited Salem , Massachusetts , and encamped in Washington Square . They loved rough-and-tumble sports , and one clay a visitor exclaimed to one , who was more obstreperous than usual , " Oh , you tiger ! " The phrase became a catch-word , a term of playful reproach . On the route to Boston some musical genius sang an impromptu line . " Oh , you tigers , do n't you know , " to the air of " Rob Roy McGregor , O ! " The Tigers by name soon began to imitate the growl of their protonymic . At the end of three cheers a " tiger " was always called for . In 1826 the same organization visited New York , being the first volunteer corps from Boston to visit another State . At a public festival the Tigers astonished the Gothamites by @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ the hosts , and gradually became adopted on all festive and joyous occasions . <p> That is great information . I was able to track the basic meaning online but was unable to get any history on it . I was reading the book " Tale Of Two Frontiers " and Three Cheers and a Tiger was a ... more

@@2907809 <p> October 22 , 2008 ) The sister of a Central Texas death row inmate was free on bond Wednesday after she was arrested in the investigation of how the convicted killer was able to get a cell phone from which threatening calls were made to a state lawmaker . <p> Prison officials confiscated the phone from death row inmate Richard Tabler on Monday and said Tabler and nine other inmates had used it to place 2,800 calls in 30 days . <p> Tablers mother was arrested Monday as she arrived in Texas from Georgia to visit her son on death row . <p> Tabler 's sister , Kristina Martinez , surrendered around 6:30 a.m . Wednesday at the Killeen Police Department and was released after posting $10,000 bond . <p> She was named in a warrant issued in Polk County . <p> Martinez and Lorraine Tabler are charged with providing a prohibited item in a corrections facility . <p> Meanwhile a shakedown of the 155,000 inmates in Texas prisons yielded 13 more cell phones and 12 chargers . <p> A phone and a charger were found in the ceiling @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Unit outside Livingston . <p> The 111 prisons in the nation 's second-largest corrections system have been locked down since Monday as the result of an order issued by Gov . John Whitmire of Houston . <p> Tabler was sentenced to death in April 2007 in Bell County for the Nov. 26 2004 murders of Teazers Gentlemens Club owner Mohamed-Amine Rahmouni , 25 , and his friend Haitham Zayed , 28 , whose bodies were found just outside of Killeen . <p> Tabler and 1st Cavalry Division Pvt . @@2907811 <p> Let me again discuss my journey thru the Yamaha S series Club IV and V cabinets into the JBL cabinets and my perspective on their output ... <p> **26;2396;TOOLONG <p> The long year of my Yamaha equipment . <p> I was doing several " parking lot shows " for a local college age venue ... I needed to provide for at least 450-600 people and the client wanted it as loud outside as I achieved inside his club . <p> Inside the club:four Yamaha S115IV ( two per side ) powered by one QSC PLX-1804. 450 Watts to each cabinet for mid highstwo Yamaha SW218V ( one per side , standing vertical with two mains stacked vertical ... more on that in a minute ) powered by one QSC PLX-3602. 1250 Watts per cabinet . <p> The venue had a ground level dance floor and stage area open to the second floor ceiling with a full balcony completely around the dance floor and I had to project into the balcony and a second room upstairs as well . So we stacked and strapped down the mains to the subs @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ I would have liked to have set up a second pair of subs , the venue did not have the electricity available to push that much of a system . I was always just a touch " weak " on the low end content to make my crew and I happy . <p> For the outside shows : We added the second pair of Yamaha SW218V subs ( these were powered by what I found available used , QSC PLX-3402 , 1100 Watts per cabinet ) . I found that system to be " wanting " ... just not quite enough low end and the stage volume of the bands made the vocals less clear than inside ... seems everyone wanted to bring their BIG amps to play outdoors . <p> Thus we upgraded yet again . We first added the third pair of mains , Yamaha S115V ( newer version ) powered by one QSC GX-5 providing 500 Watts to each cabinet . We then had the mids and highs clear above the stage volume , but we were unhappy with the low end . Thus we added a @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ ) used PLX-3402 ( from the same seller ) . <p> I liked the system even though the client commented that his last soundco had more low end and slightly more volume . ( Several of his employees told me they did not agree with that assessment ... and told me that they thought our mix was much better ... and added that the other soundco charged more than I was charging ... ) <p> But the sheer size of the system ... six 2-18 subs and six 1-15 mains , six 1-12 monitors and seven power amps , plus all the other " crap " ... transport was a problem , set up took HOURS ... we had to start our set up at 10AM for a 8pm outdoor show ... we loaded out into the trailer and van the evening before . <p> It was a nightmare . <p> I finally listened to my crew who said , " one large JBL rig would handle the events better " ... <p> ======================== <p> The JBL MRX/SRX system : <p> I bit the bullet and bought two used JBL @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ already in my inventory providing 3400 Watts per cabinet ) . <p> I bought two new JBL MRX-525 dual 15 mains for mid high . Knowing what I know today , I wish I had opted for two SRX-735 or even two of the SRX-715 ... but the MRX-525 was light enough even I could lift them onto the vertical subs . I could have used a little more high end . I powered the MRX-525 with two bridged ( used ) QSC PLX-1602 ( 1600 Watts per cabinet ) . <p> I upgraded my monitors ... ( a matter of opinion , at least the snob factor of " all JBL " was there for the clients ) . I bought four JBL JRX-112M monitors and used two ( used ) QSCV PLX-2402 for power ( 4 mixes , 450 Watts per monitor ) . <p> What pushed me over the edge to buy the JBL system was I picked up a contract to provide 8 outdoor " street dances " for a client . <p> **25;2424;TOOLONG <p> Comparison : <p> This system would actually blow the large Yamaha @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ boxes to move . This system also consumed significantly more electricity and thus was a beast to feed . <p> However , I had NO trouble providing sound for a " heavy rock " band at an outdoor event to over 1000 people ... and 2 blocks away from the event , people were dancing on the sidewalk . <p> Over the next school year , we probably worked 30-35 events with that system . All but about 5 were at the same venue ... so , we got pretty fast setting it up . From the time the client unlocked the door , we could have the system set up and room rung out ( as if we really had to change the DRPA from last week ? ) and have background music playing while we waited for the band to arrive for load in , sound check , etc . <p> Two possible improvements ... I was NEVER happy with the JRX monitors . They were " adequate " but did not get quite as loud as my " no name " CGM ARM-112 monitors and they were @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ I would like to have made was using SRX mains . I decided that having the " better " horn of the SRX series would have given me slightly more highs which would have brought some of the vocals out more clearly ... the MRX-525 was certainly " adequate " but I suspect the SRX-715/SRX-735 would have been " better than adequate " . <p> Downsizing to two MRX-515 was easy since I had already purchased them when I thought I was actually going to " expand " . I bought the two MRX-515 for my own band and for smaller events where I did not need the large SRX/MRX system ... it simply was a power hungry beast and I was getting more calls for " two speakers on a stick " . During this time , I also acquired a pair of MRX-528S subs for the same reasons , smaller venue events ... and I considered using the combined systems if I scored some " extra large show " ... <p> Then the primary client bankrupted and I realized I had no demand for the large system ... @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ changes in their life ... one moved to Tulsa for school and one got a divorce and had shared custody of the two kids ... so ... I downsized quickly ... I used most of the cash to pay off the GC and MF card . <p> During most of that time frame I used the MRX-515 powered by a stereo QSC GX-5 and the MRX-528S were powered by a pair of PLX-2402 bridged . We found the mid/highs to be weak in that system . But the quality was good . <p> I disliked the JRX monitors so I stumbled into a deal on a pair of MRX-512M . I kept my eye out for a second pair , but no luck ... then I ran into a deal on a pair of new JBL PRX-612M active ( self powered ) monitors . <p> I fell in love with the PRX-612M and worked a deal where I traded the MRX-512M and the MRX-515 " even up " for two more PRX-612M ... then I bought two PRX-615M to serve as mains . <p> Now my PRX mains and monitors @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ the MRX-515 and weighed in at less ... <p> This past spring , I had the one " DJ support " gig where we took two PRX-612M and two PRX-615M along with the two MRX-528S ( and their two bridged PLX-2402 amps ) . THAT system produced similar sound quality as the MRX/SRX system from the year before . Granted , we did not let the MRX/SRX system run that loud at the venue we normally worked simply because the genre of music and the club owner/client were " wrong " for such volume . But that system impressed my engineer and myself ... the PRX 612-615 tops with the MRX-528 subs running 115 dB at 75 ft was far better than we expected ... and the THUMP ( FYI : crossover set at 75 Hz ) we could cause involuntary voiding of your colon ... <p> THAT system was " better sounding AND MUCH LOUDER with far more punch and thump in the low end " than the large Yamaha rig . ( ... not to mention much lighter weight and easier to transport ) <p> **26;2451;TOOLONG <p> MY @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ " should " be equivalent to two MRX-528S in output potential , given all speakers were properly powered to " Program " or slightly above Program rating . <p> I stand by that belief . <p> I am not sure one pair of MRX-515 on top of four MRX-518S ( all powered at their Program rating ) would be able to provide the same SPL or volume levels as my PRX/MRX system I just described since I was running " more mid high " power and more mid high speakers . <p> I do believe that if you properly powered FOUR MRX-515 and FOUR MRX-518S that you would come very close to the same output levels I was able to achieve . <p> You would have a very " modular " system that could be configured based on the various venues and music genre and sources ( live vs recorded ) to best meet your soundco needs . <p> ================= <p> Caution : <p> Remember , running any power amp in Bridged Mono will consume more electrical power ( Amps ) and thus require more circuits in most venues . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ power amp that can produce the power required to drive the MRX mains and subs in stereo ( versus bridged ) is going to draw less current than if you buy a smaller amp and run it bridged . <p> My power amps of choice has been the QSC PLX-1 and PLX-2 generations ... their light weight and power output has meet my expectations . In the 3+ years since I stared the above journey , power amps have gotten lighter and many are now " digital power amps " . There is some concern that digital power amps will not hold up to the stress caused by long term use in Bridged Mono driving subwoofer frequencies . While I have no personal observations regarding digital power amps , I do know that I NEVER had any problems with a QSC PLX series or QSC GX series power amp . <p> ==================== <p> The above is my experiences with the listed equipment . I did not stay at a Holiday Inn Express . I am not a paid endorser . Not a professional driver on closed course . DO NOT @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ SURE YOUR SEATS ARE IN THEIR UPRIGHT POSITION . Objects in mirror are closer than they appear . Sold by weight not volume . For erections lasting more than four hours ... uhhhh , never mind that last one . <p> I cross over at 90 Hz . I usually play with different crossover points each soundcheck , but that 's where I usually end up . I think I was just expecting too much from my upgrade from yamaha club series ... more <p> buried in the " Comparison of Yamaha and JBL " post below is the information that we used 75 Hz as our crossover frequency . We made the subs JUST handle the lower frequencies and do the heavy lifting ... more 
@@2907812 <p> Of course , practicing magic , conjuring up spirits and consulting astrologers are all strictly prohibited by the Torah : <p> " There shall not be found among you one who passes his son through the fire ; a diviner , an astrologer , one who reads omens or a sorcerer . One who charms animals , one who inquires of Ov or Yideoni , or one who consults the dead . For anyone who does these is an abomination of Hashem ; and , because of these abominations , Hashem , your God , banishes the nations from before you . " <p> Famously , Maimonides explains that these activities are forbidden because they are nonsensical : <p> " And all of these things are matters of falsehood and lies , and they are the very means through which the idol worshipers fooled the nations of the world into following them . And it is not proper for the Jewish people , who are exceptionally wise , to follow after these vanities , nor to entertain the possibility that they have any benefit . As the Torah states @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ charming in Israel . " And it is stated , " For these nations that you will inherit listen to the omen-readers and charmers ; but you , not so has Hashem , your God , given you . <p> Anyone who believes in these things and things like them , and thinks in his heart that they are true and wise but that the Torah has prohibited them ; he is one of the fools and those lacking knowledge , and is grouped among the women and children whose minds are imperfect . But those who possess wisdom and sound mind know by clear demonstration that all of these things that the Torah prohibits are not things of wisdom ; rather , they are emptiness and vanity that fools stray after , and all of the paths of truth have been corrupted because of them . Because of this the Torah states , when it warns us about these vanities , " Perfect shall you be with Hashem , your God . " <p> In the Rambam 's view , which is shared by many other authorities , these @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ to Torah . @@2907815 <p> Special counsel 's team includes former Clinton Foundation lawyer , contributors to Obama , Hillary , more <p> by Brendan Kirby Updated 13 Jun 2017 at 10:30 AM <p> Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich sparked a mini-meltdown in the media Monday with a tweet challenging the fairness of the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election . <p> Gingrich , who also appeared on " The Laura Ingraham Show , " pointed to the early hires special counsel Robert Mueller has made . <p> " Republicans are delusional if they think the special counsel is going to be fair , " he tweeted . " Look who he is hiring . Check FEC reports . Time to rethink . " <p> He 's not wrong about the donations . Four top lawyers hired by Mueller have contributed tens of thousands of dollars over the years to the Democratic Party and Democratic candidates , including former President Barack Obama and President Donald Trump 's 2016 opponent , Hillary Clinton . <p> One of the hires , Jeannie Rhee , also worked as a lawyer for the Clinton Foundation @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ activist 's attempts to force Bill and Hillary Clinton to answer questions under oath about operations of the family-run charity . <p> Campaign-finance reports show that Rhee gave Clinton the maximum contributions of $2,700 in 2015 and again last year to support her presidential campaign . She also donated $2,300 to Obama in 2008 and $2,500 in 2011 . While still at the Justice Department , she gave $250 to the Democratic National Committee Services Corp . <p> Rhee also has contributed to a trio of Democratic senators : Mark Udall of New Mexico , Chris Van Hollen of Maryland , and Sheldon Whitehouse of Rhode Island . <p> James Quarles , who worked on the Watergate investigation as a young prosecutor , has an even longer history of supporting Democratic politicians . He gave $1,300 to Obama in 2007 and $2,300 in 2008 . He also gave $2,700 to Clinton last year . <p> In addition , Quarles gave money to former Sen. John Walsh ( D-Mont. ) and three current Democratic senators Ron Wyden of Oregon , Ed Markey of Massachusetts , and Robert Menendez of New Jersey @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ . $300 in 2012 . <p> Quarles did donate to a couple of GOP politicians $250 to then-Sen . George Allen ( R-Va. ) in 2006 and $2,500 to Rep. Jason Chaffetz ( R-Utah ) in 2015 . <p> Andrew Weissmann , a former Justice Department lawyer who then worked at Jenner &amp; Block until 2011 , contributed $2,300 to Obama in 2008 and $2,000 to the DNC Services Corp . in 2006 . Weissmann served as chief of the Justice Department 's criminal fraud section and worked on the Enron fraud case . <p> A fourth lawyer on Mueller 's staff , Michael Dreeben , donated $1,000 to Clinton 2006 and $250 to Obama in both 2007 and 2008 . He was deputy solicitor general and has appeared many times before the Supreme Court . <p> Media pundits generally dismissed concerns over the Democratic Party ties of the staff Mueller is building . Several Trump critics noted that Gingrich previously had tweeted that Mueller was a " superb choice to be special counsel " and that his reputation was " impeccable for honesty and integrity . " <p> Journalist @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ and The Times of London , tweeted , " Boiled cabbage Gingrich lays out the White House plan to discredit career lawman Mueller all in the service of his babbling paymaster . " <p> CNN anchor John King on Monday asked the network 's chief congressional correspondent , Manu Raju , if it should be a concern . @@2907816 <p> For Bill Babbitt , a black man , the question comes down to this : Why did Sacramento County condemn his brother Manny to death for killing a white woman but sentence his cousin Butchie 's white killer to a year in jail ? <p> " I 'm looking at all these murders that have occurred , hundreds , and I 'm thinking , how did Manny 's name come up ? " says Babbitt , who witnessed his brother 's execution by lethal injection in 1999 . <p> How did Manuel Babbitt become one of the 827 first-degree murderers chosen for California 's ultimate penalty ? The same question is being asked , in effect , by a state commission that tried to learn whether race or other inappropriate factors have been determining who gets the death penalty and who does not . <p> After failing to obtain most of the relevant data , the California Commission on the Fair Administration of Justice , appointed by the state Senate and chaired by former California Attorney General John Van de Kamp , last week called for legislation requiring prosecutors @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ to seek the death penalty . The commission also wants courts and defense lawyers , as well as prosecutors , to collect and report information showing whether race affects the outcome of murder prosecutions . <p> The commission calculated that 87 percent of first-degree murders in California could be prosecuted as death-penalty cases . But the great majority are not . The commission was unable to find out what makes the difference partly because most county district attorneys refused to cooperate with Pepperdine University law school researchers employed to construct and conduct a survey . District attorneys in each county have their own standards and procedures for evaluating murder cases . But even those internal rules are kept secret in most counties , including Sacramento . <p> Some information is available , however , from other sources . It reveals disturbing patterns . Records show administration of the death penalty is highly selective 5.6 percent of about 12,000 first-degree murderers now in prison are sentenced to death . <p> Since capital punishment was reinstated in California in 1977 , death sentences against black defendants , but not Latinos , have @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ homicide rates , victim data and the sentencing patterns of other states . <p> California 's 5-to-1 ratio of blacks on death row to blacks in the state population , measured in percentages , is much higher than the ratios in Texas , Georgia , Alabama and South Carolina . The national average is 3 to 1 . <p> Most of the raw data come from published and unpublished reports of statisticians in the state Department of Justice , the Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation , and the California Appellate Project , which provides technical support to defense lawyers appointed by the state Supreme Court in capital appeals . The project tries to collect ethnic data matching death row inmates and victims , and does its best to verify the information . <p> The problem with the high death penalty rate for blacks is n't the number arrested for homicide . Twenty-four percent of the people arrested for homicide are black , but blacks make up 36 percent of the current death row population . Latinos are 46 percent of homicide arrestees but 20 percent of death row inmates . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ large number of cases in which blacks have been sentenced to death for killing white victims . Statewide , where the victim 's race is known , nearly half of all death sentences against black defendants have involved the killing of at least one white victim . In death sentences against all ethnic groups , 59 percent have involved a white victim . Yet whites are only about 22 percent of homicide victims . <p> The numbers for Sacramento County are similar to the state figures in some respects but not others . The defendant was black in one of every three death sentences handed down in Sacramento County . A white victim was involved in four out of five death sentences against blacks . The county 's black population is about one in 10 . Sacramento 's percentage for death sentences against blacks for killing whites is about double the percentage statewide . But the percentage of white murder victims in the county also is about double the state average . <p> The county has a relatively high death-sentencing rate almost one-third higher than California 's as a whole @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ authors of " The Impact of Legally Inappropriate Factors on Death Sentencing in California Homicides , 1990-1999 . " <p> Pierce and Radelet said victim statistics are key to understanding the disparities that show up in the death row population . They concluded that in homicides with comparable circumstances , the likelihood of getting a death sentence for killing a white victim was vastly greater than for killing a black or Latino . <p> The U.S. General Accounting Office reported in 1990 that those who murder white victims are most likely to be sentenced to death nationally . <p> In Sacramento County , if the black-on-white cases were n't counted , the percentages of blacks in the population and death sentences against blacks would be about even . But in Los Angeles County , crimes committed by blacks against whites are a relatively small part of the mix , despite the county 's 43 death sentences against black defendants for killing white victims and two death sentences against white defendants for killing black victims . <p> Some counties , including Alameda and San Bernardino , have n't sentenced a single @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ the death penalty was reinstated in 1977 . Sacramento did so in two cases . <p> Albert Locher , Sacramento County 's assistant district attorney , says his office takes race or ethnicity into account only when it must identify a perpetrator described by witnesses in racial terms , or in hate crimes , which by definition may involve crimes committed because of the victims ' race or ethnicity . <p> He also says that not filing a death penalty case because there are too many in a particular category , such as black crimes against whites , would be inappropriate . <p> None of the numbers proves that race is the reason why some murderers have been sentenced to death but not others . And much more information would be needed to prove or disprove a connection between the district attorneys and any bias that may exist . <p> The problem may lie elsewhere , within or outside the criminal justice system . Pierce and Radelet suggested bias may enter a case when police investigators work harder to collect evidence in the deaths of white victims . <p> " @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ the door , " Locher says . " The district attorney does n't investigate the cases or have an effect on who commits what crimes . " <p> Even Bill Babbitt thinks race was just one of several reasons why his brother was put to death . Among other possible factors : Poor people like Manny Babbitt often do not get good lawyers . Manny Babbitt 's lawyer later resigned from the bar with disciplinary charges pending . <p> The legislative proposal by the Commission on the Fair Administration of Justice does n't cover all the possible reasons why so many blacks are on death row . And the recommendation already is being opposed by police , prosecutors and victims ' representatives , who say there 's been no evidence of abuse by prosecutors in three decades of deciding which murders warrant the death penalty . <p> The critics also do n't want prosecutors to adopt formal , written , public policies on when they 'll seek the death penalty , as the commission has recommended . Such documents would serve primarily to create new grounds for condemned prisoners to @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ may be right . Maybe racial factors have n't been influencing prosecutors ' decisions to ask for the death penalty . If that 's true , though , developing and disclosing more information might reassure Bill Babbitt and the state 's policymakers , and it would improve public confidence in California 's criminal justice system.About the writer:Claire Cooper has studied race and the California death penalty for the University of Southern California 's Annenberg Institute for Justice and Journalism . <p> See a larger version of this graphic <p> Brian Baer , 2003 / bbaer@sacbee.com <p> Click on photo to enlarge <p> Bill Babbitt , pictured , thinks race was just one of several reasons why his brother was put to death . Among other possible factors : Poor people like Manny Babbitt often do not get good lawyers . Manny Babbitt 's lawyer later resigned from the bar with disciplinary charges pending . Brian Baer , 2003 / bbaer@sacbee.com

@@2907819 <p> TOM AND MOLLIE WELCHThomas Adderson Welch , son of William Adderson and Florence Isabelle Smith Welch , was born in 1867 in Jacksonville , Illinois . He lived with his mother when his parents divorced when he was three years old . He and his mother moved to Girard , Kansas to live near her brother and he was nine before she remarried . She married Benjamin Hill , a widower with three sons of his own . They had another son before they decided to take their five sons and move West . Tom was 13 in 1880 when the family joined a wagon train headed for the Northwest . They left the train when they got to Green River , Wyoming and settled down there . They added their only daughter , Kate , when they lived in Green River . ( She became the wife of Zebulon Edwards . ) We can only imagine the responsibilities he must have shouldered being a part of a real pioneer wagon train . We do know he learned to drive a team . He was employed as a stable @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ hired to drive the leg between Big Sandy and South Pass in 1881 . He was then all of fourteen years old but was entrusted with both passengers and freight and was able to perform the job without incident . He was thus employed for a few years.Tom came to this area from Lander about 1888 . His parents freighted from Green River to Vernal but Tom put down roots when he homesteaded a place on Henry 's Fork at the bottom of the now Anderson ranch and started raising cattle.Remember , this was all unclaimed open range at the time . There were no meadows to irrigate or fences to fix so one had time to work with cattle , keep the range sheep-free , and court his girl . Tom married Mary Ann ( called Mollie ) Stoll , daughter of George and Mary Ann Stoll , early settlers in the region . They raised their three children here.Tom prospered . His herd of cattle grew and , in 1904 , he sold his place on Henry 's Fork to Mackey Land and Livestock Co. and bought property @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ found . He really felt that sheep were only good for eating or wearing and had a cattleman 's true antipathy for the raising of them.Tom and Mollie acquired a lot of property on Burntfork and owned many cows . Tom became a well-known businessman in Green River when he and Dr. Hawk built and operated the Tomahawk Hotel there . Maybe he Just wanted a place to stay when he went to town but it was a successful venture for a number of years . Hard times came and this property did n't pay for itself so he got out of the hotel business.Tom is said to have been a good friend of Butch Cassidy and the Wild Bunch . He refused to ever say much about the things he knew of them . He did insist that Butch visited him in Green River long after he was supposed to have been killed in South America.Tom was over 70 when he retired to their house in Green River where Mollie died at 83 in 1956 . Tom lived there another seven years before he followed her in 1963 at @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ both buried in the Green River Cemetery . <p> Big Horn River Pilot March 23 , 1898 , page 3 . JWSThe genial face of T.P. Walsh ( Irish Tom ) was beaming on the ladies at the St. Patrick 's ball . <p> Thermopolis Independent May 03 , 1907 , page 3 . JIWSCattle Outfit Sold.Jones and Walsh yesterday sold the z. -o-z. cattle outfit which they owned to Robert J. Price . Mr. Walsh , better known as " Irish Tom , " wishes to deny the rumor prevalent that he will close out all his cattle interests and retire . The z-o-z was only one of the companies in which he is interested and Tom is by far too good a man to retire at his present youthful age . Robert Price is a young man of ability and experience in the cow business and his many friends wish him unlimited success in his latest venture . <p> Wind River Mountaineer June 05 , 1908 , page 2 . Mr. Walsh is one of the popular stockgrowers of this part of the country , while his fair bride is the sister of Mrs. Jerry Ryan of this city . She visited here several years ago , when an acquaintance was formed that ripened into something closer that ended in matrimony . She is a charming young lady and made a host of friends during her visit here . Mr. and Mrs. Walsh will receive a rousing welcome on their return . <p> Thermopolis Record July 20 , 1911 , page 6 . @@2907821 <p> Just looking through my correspondence with a relative of Flight Lieutenant K. McL . " Ken " Gillies of 66 Squadron ( who was killed fighting in the Battle of Britain in his Spitfire-whose grave , Simon and I visited recently to pay our respects ) and I thought back to the losses of men like him and those he knew in 66 Squadron . This Squadron suffered less than say 253 or 257 or even 501 Squadron or others but even so , goes to show the effect these losses must have had on those who flew with and knew these men . <p> Amongst the general stories of the losses involved in the Battle of Britain by cold statistics alone are the human stories hidden by these facts . @@2907822 <p> Nourishing the Heart of Your Petposted by Sara , from Institute of HeartMath May 1 , 2011 <p> Cort <p> " I am the rug beneath your feet that buffers you from all the harshness of life . " Dog <p> I have had the gift of four dogs , a cat and two horses in my life . I fed them , groomed them and loved them . I cared for them in a multitude of ways , going to great lengths to make sure they were healthy , and I worried when they were not . Perhaps I cared so much for my pets because they cared so much for me . My pets have been my close companions , providing me with love , warmth , happiness , laughter and friendship . They have taught me unconditional love , to be more patient with life and to enjoy the simple moments . <p> A lot has been written about the benefits of having a pet , but there 's more to that relationship than many of us realize . A lot of pet lovers surely will appreciate @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of Research Dr. Rollin McCraty conducted with his 14-year-old son and 15-year-old dog . <p> Institute of HeartMath had already found that heart-rhythm entrainment , or synchronization , occurs between people when they are feeling love and care for each other . Rollin wanted to see if the same thing happened between people and their pets . So he put electrodes on his son Josh and his dog Mabel . <p> " We used two Holter ( electrocardiogram ) recorders , one fitted on Mabel and the other on Josh , " Rollin wrote in his paper , The Energetic Heart : Bioelectromagnetic Interactions Within and Between People . " We synchronized the recorders and placed Mabel in one of our labs . Josh then entered the room where Mabel was waiting , sat down and proceeded to consciously feel feelings of love towards Mabel . " <p> You can see what happened in the graph below . <p> The higher , irregular vertical lines indicate a period of incoherence . The lower , smoother vertical lines indicated a period of coherence . <p> As Josh sent feelings of love @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ more ordered and coherent , and this change appears to have influenced Mabels heart rhythms , which then also became more coherent and in sync with Joshs heart rhythms . <p> If you 've ever wondered what goes on in your dogs mind , or heart , when you leave home , this may help : When Josh left the room , Mabels heart rhythms became much more chaotic and incoherent , suggesting initial separation anxiety , as you can see in the graph . <p> Excited by these results , Rollin decided to try the same experiment with Ellen and her horse Tonopah . <p> The results were similar . In the graph below you can see a beautiful shift into more order and coherence in the horses heart rhythms and synchronization with Ellens heart rhythms . <p> Rollins conclusion : " Although more research needs to be done , it appears that there is a type of communication occurring between people and pets above and beyond body language or verbal communication . I believe well see in future research studies that we are affecting each others moods and attitudes @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ radiate from our hearts In our work with pets and their owners , were seeing that a pet owner can create what we call a heart-filled environment when practicing heart-focused techniques . The pets respond by becoming more affectionate , more animated and more connected with the pet owner . " <p> With my last dog Cort , I often used the basic steps of a very simple and fun technique we at the Institute of HeartMath teach young children called the Shift and Shine Technique to create a heart-filled environment . I chose this simple technique because my relationship with Cort often was so simple . <p> Here are the steps : <p> Step 1 . Heart Attention : Begin by putting your attention on the area around your heart or the center of your chest . <p> Step 2 . Heart Breathing : Now pretend to breathe in and out of your heart . <p> Step 3 : Heart Feeling : Think of someone or something that makes you feel happy and then shine that feeling . <p> Feel the warm feeling in your heart when you feel @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ the warmth from the sun . When we feel love , appreciation or care for someone , or something special , its like the warmth from the sun shining in our hearts . Shine that warm feeling into the environment with love and care for your pet . <p> ( Adapted from the Shift and Shine Technique ) <p> Using this technique at any time would deepen our connection . Using it when either Cort or I was agitated , worried or stressed would de-stress both Cort and me . Try it with your pet and comment on your experience . <p> Sara Childre is President and CEO of the non-profit Institute of HeartMath . Since 1991 , Sara has helped oversee and develop HeartMath trainings , educational products and scientific programs . She was appointed vice president and CFO of the institute in 1992 , then president and CEO in 1998.

@@2907826 <p> The Missorium of Theodosius I is a silver ceremonial dish that is 29 in ( 79 cm ) across and weighs about 34 lb ( 15 kg ) . It was probably made in Constantinople in 388 CE to commemorate the rule of Theodosius I , the last Roman emperor to rule both the Eastern and Western Empires . The ornate dish is one of the best surviving examples of late antique imperial imagery and features Theodosius flanked by his co-emperors , an iconography that was later adopted by Western Christianity and given what name ? <p> The missorium of Theodosius I is a large ceremonial silver dish preserved in the Real Academia de Historia , in Madrid , Spain . It was probably made in Constantinople for the tenth anniversary ( decennalia ) in 388 of the reign of the Emperor Theodosius I , the last Emperor to rule both the Eastern and Western Empires . It is one of the best surviving examples of Late Antique Imperial imagery and one of finest examples of late Roman goldsmith work .

@@2907830 <p> Special counsel 's team includes former Clinton Foundation lawyer , contributors to Obama , Hillary , more <p> by Brendan Kirby Updated 13 Jun 2017 at 10:30 AM <p> Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich sparked a mini-meltdown in the media Monday with a tweet challenging the fairness of the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election . <p> Gingrich , who also appeared on " The Laura Ingraham Show , " pointed to the early hires special counsel Robert Mueller has made . <p> " Republicans are delusional if they think the special counsel is going to be fair , " he tweeted . " Look who he is hiring . Check FEC reports . Time to rethink . " <p> He 's not wrong about the donations . Four top lawyers hired by Mueller have contributed tens of thousands of dollars over the years to the Democratic Party and Democratic candidates , including former President Barack Obama and President Donald Trump 's 2016 opponent , Hillary Clinton . <p> One of the hires , Jeannie Rhee , also worked as a lawyer for the Clinton Foundation @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ activist 's attempts to force Bill and Hillary Clinton to answer questions under oath about operations of the family-run charity . <p> Campaign-finance reports show that Rhee gave Clinton the maximum contributions of $2,700 in 2015 and again last year to support her presidential campaign . She also donated $2,300 to Obama in 2008 and $2,500 in 2011 . While still at the Justice Department , she gave $250 to the Democratic National Committee Services Corp . <p> Rhee also has contributed to a trio of Democratic senators : Mark Udall of New Mexico , Chris Van Hollen of Maryland , and Sheldon Whitehouse of Rhode Island . <p> James Quarles , who worked on the Watergate investigation as a young prosecutor , has an even longer history of supporting Democratic politicians . He gave $1,300 to Obama in 2007 and $2,300 in 2008 . He also gave $2,700 to Clinton last year . <p> In addition , Quarles gave money to former Sen. John Walsh ( D-Mont. ) and three current Democratic senators Ron Wyden of Oregon , Ed Markey of Massachusetts , and Robert Menendez of New Jersey @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ . $300 in 2012 . <p> Quarles did donate to a couple of GOP politicians $250 to then-Sen . George Allen ( R-Va. ) in 2006 and $2,500 to Rep. Jason Chaffetz ( R-Utah ) in 2015 . <p> Andrew Weissmann , a former Justice Department lawyer who then worked at Jenner &amp; Block until 2011 , contributed $2,300 to Obama in 2008 and $2,000 to the DNC Services Corp . in 2006 . Weissmann served as chief of the Justice Department 's criminal fraud section and worked on the Enron fraud case . <p> A fourth lawyer on Mueller 's staff , Michael Dreeben , donated $1,000 to Clinton 2006 and $250 to Obama in both 2007 and 2008 . He was deputy solicitor general and has appeared many times before the Supreme Court . <p> Media pundits generally dismissed concerns over the Democratic Party ties of the staff Mueller is building . @@2907831 <p> some time prior to their first birthdays . My first doodle had almost no shedding until about 7 months and then , she began shedding massive quantities of fur . I was very concerned as in all that I had read about them , I had not seen anything about this event and was under the impression that they did not she 'd ! ! After about two months , the shedding stopped and she never had a problem with it again . Her coat changed from the downy soft fur to a bit more curly and slightly more coarse . My 2nd and 3rd doodles did not have major coat change cycles , however , their fur did change texture slightly and both of them have a more curly coat than my first one did . Although 4 months old seems early , it is possible that is what you are experiencing . Thorough and frequent brushing helps to control the loose fur flying while they go through this . Otherwise , check with your vet to see if there might be some other cause for the shedding . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ . @@2907841 <p> Flemish artist Pieter Bruegel earned the nickname " Peasant " a reference to the subjects of his artwork painting cheerful scenes of daily life . However , in 1562 , he displayed a taste for the macabre with The Triumph of Death , a panoramic landscape of death and destruction wrought by hordes of skeletons that has been interpreted as an allegorical depiction of the horrors of war . How was the Catherine wheel , a common 16th-century execution device that appears in the painting , used to kill ? <p> The painting is a panoramic landscape of death : the sky in the distance is blackened by smoke from burning cities and the sea is littered with shipwrecks . Armies of skeletons advance on the hapless living , who either flee in terror or try vainly to fight back . Skeletons kill people in a variety of ways -- slitting throats , hanging , drowning , and even hunting with skeletal dogs . In the foreground , skeletons haul a wagon full of skulls , and ring the bell that signifies the death knell of the world . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ plays along ; a starving dog nibbles at the face of a child ; a cross sits lonely and impotent in the center of the painting . People flee into a tunnel decorated with crosses whilst a skeleton on horseback slaughters people with a scythe . The painting clearly depicts people of different social backgrounds -- from peasants and soldiers to nobles and even a king and a cardinal -- being taken by death indiscriminately . 
@@2907842 <p> Welcome to " The Schnauzer Rescue Board " . The purpose of this board is to help facilitate schnauzer rescue by helping match schnauzers needing homes with those seeking to adopt a schnauzer . Postings pertaining to schnauzers needing homes or individuals seeking to adopt a rescue schnauzer for all three schnauzer types ( minis , giants and standards ) as well as schnauzer mixes are welcomed . <p> If you are looking for a " breeding " dog please do not bother looking here , the point of rescue is to reduce pet population not contribute to the problem and rescuers will have had the dogs spayed/neutered prior to placement . <p> This is a public bulletin board but it is monitored and inappropriate posts will be removed . <p> Please refrain from debating , flaming or using the board as a " chat " board or personal soap box ... these type of posts take away from the purpose of this board . Note we do have a separate board for these type of postings at Schnauzer Chat Area ... please use it ! <p> Please spay/neuter @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ only responsible thing to do ! <p> While dog/puppy sales post are not allowed , we do not suggest giving away " free dogs " ... instead ask a nominal adoption fee and donate it to your local humane society or a rescue group . Please read " Free Pets " to understand why giving away a free pet is not advisable . <p> Please check the board for dogs in your area before posting you want to adopt ( there is a search facility to assist you ) . Also try contacting a schnauzer rescuer in your area and check your local shelters . Local adoptions tend to work out best . <p> Please do not post a request to " adopt a puppy " , such requests will be deleted . This is a rescue board not a place to make breeder contacts . <p> Please use the contact information provided in the post to communicate offline . Postings on the board are not permanent and are removed to make room for new postings . <p> Cross postings are welcome , but please include the source of the @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ current ( many websites are not updated very frequent ... verify the information is current before posting here ) . Please also follow up on it and notify me when the dog is no longer available . <p> Please note the schnauzer rescue board nor its webmaster are affliated with any individuals or groups that request donations via this board . There is no responsibility assumed for the validity of such requests .... and as with any type of solitication , it is always advisable for donors to do their own verification prior to sending a contribution . <p> NOTE : Use the " Next Page " button at the bottom of the post listings to see more postings &amp;nbsp To return to previous pages use your browser " Back " button . <p> The webmaster does not screen or verify notices posted on this site and makes no claims to the accuracy of this information . This site and its webmaster bear no responsibility for claims or damages arising from the use of this service . However , if you become aware of a fraudulent post , please notify @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ <p> Please also be advised that we do not meet and evaluate the dogs so can offer no assurances about the identity , health , or temperament of any dogs listed . Potential adopters need to ask questions of those placing the dogs and evaluate if the dog fits their lifestyles . Get as much background as you can before making the decision to adopt . Remember ADOPTION IS A LIFETIME COMMITTEMENT ! ! Placers , be advised there is no prescreening of potential adopters done on this forum ... so please properly screen applicants before adopting out your dogs . If you find someone totally unsuitable as an adopter , please advise the webmaster and their posting will be removed . <p> This site is NOT affiliated with the AMSC , any email lists or other bulletins boards . It is run independent site ran by a fellow schanuzer lover in an effort to help facilitate schnauzer rescues . <p> Thank you ! ! <p> For problem , comments or information related to this board email webmaster ( Mary ) at **28;2548;TOOLONG you for your help ! !

@@2907844 <p> For millions of years , flowers have dotted the landscape . Their simple manipulative evolutionary innovation using color and scent to trick insects and animals into doing their bidding has persisted and proven to be highly effective . Today , flowering plants are among the most diverse classes of life on the planet . <p> Far from the garden varieties , these massive flowers show just how far the adaptations have been pushed . <p> Rafflesia arnoldii <p> Among all of the large flowers , Rafflesia arnoldi produces the largest single bloom . Native to rainforests of Indonesia and Malaysia , the flower can be up to three feet in diameter and has weighed in at more than 24 pounds . <p> More than its size , however , Rafflesia is known for its scent . Dubbed the " corpse flower , " the large bloom reeks of rotting meat an adaptation it has developed to attract the flies that help pollinate the plant . <p> The unusual flower only grows on the tendrils of the Tetrastigma vine , which in turn only grows in pristine rainforest meaning Rafflesia @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ for " largest flower " is not always as simple as measuring blooms . <p> Indeed , Amorphophallus titanumwhich has an inflorescence that can grow 10 feet in height , is not small by any definition . Unlike Rafflesia , however , this large structure is not a single flower , but rather hundreds of small buds on a single stalk . <p> Native to Sumatra , Indonesia , the plant remains rare there but is now cultivated in gardens around the world . Still , blooms remain infrequent both in the wild and in captivity . <p> Like Rafflesia , Amorphophallus titanum attracts pollinators with the smell of rotting meat , meaning that the two flowers battle for the nickname " corpse flower " in addition to the largest flower superlative . <p> Corypha umbraculifera , better known as the " Talipot palm , " is the largest flowering plant with branched inflorescence . This simply means that , instead of budding off a single stalk , the flowers of the Talipot bud from tiny branches attached to the main stalk . <p> This flowering inflorescence is the largest @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ than 25 feet in length . <p> Perhaps the best example of this is Pando , a clonal colony of a single male tree that is thought to cover more than 107 acres in Utah . More than 47,000 trees , or stems , sprout from a single root system that is thought to be more than 80,000 years old making Pando one of the worlds oldest living organisms in addition to one of the largest . <p> Pando , however , does not match the size or age of Posidonia , a flowering grass that proliferates in the Mediterranean and off the coast of Australia . Like quaking aspen , Posidonia oceanica grows in clonal colonies . <p> One such colony , discovered in the Mediterranean in 2006 , is nearly five miles across and thought to be more than 100,000 years old .

It would be the nerds ' word against his and he could easily bring up the business of the webcam in the shower . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ would all the girls . If Ernest went to the principal , he could end up being expelled for installing that webcam instead of gaining justice for himself and his friend . <p> Miss Ross , + Ernest said , surprisingly sharp , I 'm going to make them pay . They will pay for what they did . And you will help me . You will do EXACTLY AS I SAY ! + He lifted his fist and slammed it down ; an act which might have looked ludicrous , given his geeky appearance , but which in fact looked rather formidable , because of the almost firy look he pierced her with as he spoke . <p> When he had finished explaining his plan to her , Miss Ross got up from her chair and walked a few paces across the floor . She looked up at the almost invisible hole above the door . She fancied seeing a tiny reflection of light in there , but she could n't be sure . For all she knew he had removed the device . How he 'd gotten into @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ it , but she supposed a clever customer such as Ernest had been able to obtain a spare key . Perhaps he even knew how to jimmy the not too complex locking mechanism . I did n't , actually . That was a stroke of luck . I was hoping to get something useful , but I was thinking more along the lines of you either ... you know ... taking a ' refreshment ' in here ... or maybe making a phone call to someone ... there 's a microphone on that thing , you know. + She looked up at the hole again . I could go up and show those pictures to the principal myself , right now , and be done with it. + Ernest smiled . You do n't want to do that , + he said . If this drug thing gets out , you 'll never land another teaching job again . There 's a risk , I admit that . But it 's not too big a risk , really . Nobody comes down there after school hours this whole place is deserted after five o ' clock . There 's a rent-a-cop who @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ head through the main doors . He certainly wo n't go down to the basement . It 's perfectly safe. + <p> And ... they : You are absolutely certain they wo n't create any trouble for us after it 's done ? + Ernest nodded . @@2907849 <p> Provisional Item : an item of work identified as provisional in the Contract Bills to be carried out by the Contractor if instructed to do so by the Architect under clause 13.2 . <p> Provisional Quantities : an estimated quantity of work identified as provisional in the Contract Bills , where the actual quantity could not be accurately determined when the bills of quantities were prepared , to be carried out by the Contractor if instructed to do so by the Architect under clause 13.2 . <p> Provisional Sum : a sum provided in the Contract Bills for work or for costs , which could not be entirely foreseen , defined or detailed when the bills of quantities were prepared , to be paid to the Contractor if instructed by the Architect under clause 13.2 to carry out such work or incur such costs . <p> This definition of " provisional item " arises in the new SFBC . Otherise , provisional quantities and provisional sums could also be called provisional items in the broader sense . <p> Now , provisional item is a kind of provisional quantity item @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ I do not think that we need to call it as such separately because it would cause confusion . Just treat it as one kind of provisional quantities should be OK . <p> Both provisional items and provisional quantities items included in the Main Contract are to be carried out by the Contractor . If included in a Nominated Sub-Contract , then by the Nominated Sub-Contractor . <p> Works covered by provisional sums are to be carried out by the Main Contractor , but the Architect can instruct to change a provisional sum to a prime cost sum . <p> SFC 2005 refers . I would like to know the difference between Cl. 13.2(a)- carrying out of work covered by Provision Item and Cl. 13.2(b)- Expenditure of Provision Sum Is that provisional item has to ... more

@@2907851 <p> It was interesting that whenever TPTB at EDGE OF NIGHT recast the role of " Laurie Ann " that they completely went against type of the previous performer . Laurie Ann #1 was portrayed by series star JOHN LARKIN 's ( " Mike Karr " ) real life daughter VICTORIA LARKIN . She was a " toe-head " blonde . She portrayed " Laurie Ann " from 1959 to 1961 . The character was born in the storyline sometime in 1959 I believe . <p> As a sidenote : his other daughter SHEILA later portrayed " Dana Sculley 's " ( GILLIAN ANDERSON ) mother on THE X-FILES . JOHN LARKIN was also married to actress TERI KEANE ( EDGE 's " Martha Spears Marceau " ) at one point and TERI had a daughter named SHARON ( do n't know if she was LARKIN 's daughter or from another marriage ) . She played the role when ANN FLOOD entered the picture . Mike was then being portrayed by LARRY HUGO . LARKIN had left EDGE in 1961 to move to Hollywood . <p> In 1965 KATHY CODY replaced BRACKEN and CODY had light blonde hair . CODY later went to DARK SHADOWS and portrayed " Hallie &amp; Carrie Stokes " . CODY left EDGE in late 1967 or very early 1968 . She was " Laurie Ann " during the infamous spy storyline and also when " Liz Hillyer " ( ALBERTA GRANT ) was taken in by " Mike &amp; Nancy " after " Orin 's " ( LESTER RAWLINS ) mental collapse when " Laura " ( MILLETTE ALEXANDER ) died . This was when " Laurie Ann " and " Liz " became as close as like " sisters " . <p> In early 1968 EMILY PRAGER replaced CODY as " Laurie Ann " #4 and " laurie Ann " became a brunette again . PRAGER 's hair was very dark brown . EMILY PRAGER left a huge impression in the role and is often @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ . She of course played out the great " Keith Whitney/Jonah Lockwood " storyline . PRAGER was written out in early 1973 . PRAGER was the actress to be in the role when " Laurie " married " Vic Lamont " . <p> The " Laurie Ann " #5 was JEANNE RUSKIN who was a redhead ( same color as ANN FLOOD ) and she appeared on the show from 1973 to 1975 . <p> The final " Laurie " ( #6 ) was played by LINDA COOK from 1975 to 1978 and then returned to role in 1984 when " Mike &amp; Nancy " were reunited with their daughter for the series ending . COOK had lt. brown hair so " Laurie " became a brunette again . I personally enjoyed EMILY PRAGER and LINDA COOK best in the part but for different reasons . LINDA COOK is a very appealing actress and I enjoyed her other roles on LOVING , ATWT &amp; GL as well . I was glad that they brought back the character for EDGE 's finale .
